Economic historian | party = [[German National People's Party| DNVP]] | spouse = Eva Buchfink | partner = | alma_mater = [[University of Jena| Jena]] | children = 1 s, 2 d | years_active = }} '''Friedrich Lütge''' (21 October 1901 - 25 August 1968) was a [[Germany|German]] economist, [[Social history |social historian]] and [[Economic history |economic historian]].{{cite web|url=http://agso.uni-graz.at/marienthal/biografien/luetge_friedrich.htm|title=Friedrich Lütge|date=June 2008|author=Reinhard Müller (compiler)|publisher= Archiv für die Geschichte der Soziologie in Österreich, Karl-Franzens-Universität Graz| accessdate=25 October 2018}}{{cite web|url= https://www.persee.fr/doc/ahess_0395-2649_1969_num_24_2_422076| title=Friedrich Lütge [note biographique] |pages=568-570| work=Annales, Année 1969 |publisher= Persées (UMS3602), École Normale Supérieure de Lyon|author=[[:de:Hermann Kellenbenz |Hermann Kellenbenz]]| accessdate=25 October 2018}} He taught at the [[HHL Leipzig Graduate School of Management |Leipzig Graduate School of Management (HHL)]] and at the [[University of Leipzig]] between 1940 and 1947, then moving on to the [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich]] where he taught till a few months before he died. Through his research work between 1949 and 1968 he exercised a great influence on the understanding of economic history in West Germany. Together with [[Wilhelm Abel]] and [[:de:Günther Franz |Günther Franz]] he contributed decisively to research into [[:de:Agrargeschichte |agrarian history]] in [[Germany]]. He was instrumental in ensuring that social and economic history emerged as an alternative strand to the prism of [[historical materialism]] that was mainstream in many German universities during this period. From this followed an insistence in his economic research that the subject needs to be studied not simply from a theoretical quasi-mathematical standpoint, but also empirically and in the context of broader historical considerations.Jörg Rode: Die Gesellschaft für Sozial- und Wirtschaftsgeschichte (1961–1998). Stuttgart 1998, p. 28 == Life and works == === Provenance and early years === Friedrich Karl Lütge was born into a [[Protestant]] family at the start of the twentieth century at [[Wernigerode]], a midsized town located in the [[Harz |Harz Mountains]] between [[Hanover]] and [[Halle (Saale)| Halle]]. He was the older of twin brothers. There were also two younger siblings. His father was a captain in the German merchant navy who was much involved with [[Kamerun]] trade, but died in 1905. As a child Friedrich Lütge suffered from a spinal disease which confined him to bed for three years.Wilhelm Abel, Knut Borchardt, Hermann Kellenbenz, Wolfgang Zorn (Hrsg.): Wirtschaft, Geschichte und Wirtschaftsgeschichte. Festschrift zum 65. Geburtstag von Friedrich Lütge. Fischer, Stuttgart 1966, pp. 1–7 On 23 September 1918, while still at school he found himself recruited into an [[Regiment |infantry regiment]] as a [[Fahnenjunker |junior officer (''"Fahnenjunker"'')]], but by this time the [[First World War]] was nearly over and he was never sent into the fighting of it. However, in February 1919 he found himself taken into the [[Freikorps |Freikorps (''"militia" unit'')]] of [[:de:Adolf von Oven |Adolf von Oven]] in [[Berlin]], and he was involved in the putting down of the [[Spartacist uprising |Spartacus uprising]].Andreas Dornheim: Die deutsche Agrargeschichte in der NS-Zeit und die Lehrstuhl-Berufungen nach 1945 in Westdeutschland. In: Zeitschrift für Agrargeschichte und Agrarsoziologie 53 (2005), p. 49. It was only in 1921 that he passed his [[Abitur |Abitur (school leaving exams)]] which opened the way to university-level education. In 1921 Lütge enrolled at the [[University of Freiburg]] where he studied [[:de:Volkswirtschaftslehre |Applied economics (Volkswirtschaft)]] and [[History]] on a course directed by [[:de:Georg von Below |Georg von Below]]. That was followed by a term at the [[University of Marburg]] where he was taught by [[Albert Brackmann]] and [[:de:Wilhelm Busch (Historiker) |Wilhelm Busch]]. He concluded his student studies at the [[University of Jena]] where he was supervised for his doctorate by [[:de:Franz Gutmann (Ökonom)|Franz Gutmann]]. Importantly for Lütge 's subsequent academic career, it was Gutmann who awakened his interest in [[:de:Agrargeschichte |agrarian history]]. His doctoral dissertation concerned "The liberation of the peasantry in the County of Wernigerode". He was obliged to [[:de:Werkstudent |work his way through his university years]] in order to support himself and his widowed mother.{{cite web|url=http://www.igghhl.de/luetge.pdf|title=Prof. Dr. rer. pol. Dr. Phil. Friedrich Lütge|work=Rektor vom 1. Mai 1945 bis zum 4. Februar 1946|publisher=Interessengemeinschaft Geschichte der Handelshochschule Leipzig|accessdate=25 October 2018}} Briefly, between 15 October and 16 November 1923, he belonged to the so-called [[Black Reichswehr]]. Unusually, on 1 December 1928 Friedrich Lütge was awarded a second doctorate. This time his dissertation concerned the history of the book trade in Jena, including the impact of the invention of printing. The work was supervised by Georg Menz. While working on this doctorate he was also employed in [[Jena]] as a private researcher by the economist-statistician [[:de:Ludwig Elster |Ludwig Elster]]. Projects on which he worked with Elster included the fourth edition of the "Wörterbuchs der Volkswirtschaftslehre" (''loosely, "Lexicon of Applied Economics"'') and the [[:de:Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik |"Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik" (''loosely "Year books of National Economy and Statistics"'')]].Erich Maschke: Friedrich Lütge [Nachruf]. In: Historische Zeitschrift. vol. 208 (1969), section 3, pp. 772–774 He also authored a celebratory booklet in respect of the fiftieth anniversary of the [[:de:Gustav Fischer Verlag |Gustav Fischer Verlag (publishing house)]]: research for this commission supported and influenced the doctorate on which he was working at the same time. In 1929 he obtained a permanent position with [[:de:Gustav Fischer Verlag |Fischer]] as a literary editor and academic researcher. At Fischer he was entrusted with producing a number of works, mostly concerned with [[:de:Volkswirtschaftslehre |Applied economics (Volkswirtschaft)]] and [[Economic History]]{{cite web|url=https://www.deutsche-biographie.de/gnd122795784.html#ndbcontent|title=Lütge, Friedrich: Wirtschaftshistoriker, * 21.10.1901 Wernigerode, † 25.8.1968 München. (evangelisch)|author=Wolfgang Zorn|work=[[Neue Deutsche Biographie]]|volume=15 |date=1987|page=476|isbn=3-428-00196-6|publisher=[[:de:Duncker & Humblot |Duncker & Humblot]], Berlin & [[:de:Historische Kommission bei der Bayerischen Akademie der Wissenschaften |Historische Kommission bei der Bayerischen Akademie der Wissenschaften (HiKo)]], München |accessdate=26 October 2018}} It was also in 1929 that Friedrich Lütge married Eva Buchfink, a daughter of General Ernst Buchfinck. The marriage produced one recorded son and two daughters. === Jena in the 1930s === During the early 1930s he pursued his career with the publisher in parallel with his academic researches, publishing several essays on social policy and agricultural history. In 1934 he published a significant piece of work in which he pointed out that in central Germany as early as the [[early modern period]] a form of [[Manorialism |landlordship and tenancy]] existed which was based not on [[Socage |service obligation]], but simply the handing over of produce. That contrasted with he versions of [[manorialism]] that was normal in the northern and southern parts of [[Holy Roman empire|Germany]]. He followed this up in 1937 with a broadened study of the German agrarian economy, taking his research back to the middle ages and, in particular, to the [[Carolingian dynasty |Carolingian era]]. This meant that there had been fundamental regional variations in land tenure arrangements in Germany far earlier than had hitherto been believed.{{cite web|pages=406-407|author1=Magdalena Pernold (author), Universität Innsbruck| author2=Prof. Dr. Alois Niederstätter (supervisor)|url=https://webapp.uibk.ac.at/ojs/index.php/historiascribere/article/viewFile/182/106 |title=Leibeigenschaft und Grundherrschaft im mittelalterlichen Mitteleuropa |date=2010| publisher=Leopold-Franzens-Universität Innsbruck|accessdate=26 October 2018}} That same year he saw to the posthumous publication of the "Outline history of the German rural economy in the middle ages" (''"Geschichte der deutschen Landwirtschaft des Mittelalters in ihren Grundzügen"'') by his former tutor, [[:de:Georg von Below |Georg von Below]], using manuscripts that von Below had left behind when he died ten years earlier.Georg von Below: "Geschichte der deutschen Landwirtschaft des Mittelalters in ihren Grundzügen". Aus den hinterlassenen Manuskripten herausgegeben von Friedrich Lütge [produced posthumously from von Below's manuscripts by Friedrich Lütge]. Fischer, Jena 1937. 1933 was the year of the [[Machtergreifung|National Socialist take-over]]. It was also the year in which Lütge joined the [[German National People's Party| German National People's Party (''"Deutschnationale Volkspartei, "'' / DNVP)]], though this party had dissolved itself by the end of that year.{{cite book|author1=Jörg Opitz (author) |author2=Uwe Hossfeld (editor-compiler)|author3=Rudiger Stutz (editor-compiler)|title=Kämpferische Wissenschaft: Studien zur Universität Jena im Nationalsozialismus| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bJCxIkTe1gYC&pg=PA476|year=2003|publisher=Böhlau Verlag Köln Weimar| isbn=978-3-412-04102-1 |pages=471–518}} He also had close connections with the anti-[[Nazi party|government]] [[Confessing Church]]. He would later insist that his various longstanding memberships of associations connected with the army, notably the [[Stahlhelm, Bund der Frontsoldaten |Stahlhelm]], afforded him a measure of independence in his interactions with the [[Nazi Germany |National Socialist state]]. When the [[Stahlhelm, Bund der Frontsoldaten |Stahlhelm]] was forcibly merged into the party's own [[Sturmabteilung |Sturmabteilung (SA)]] paramilitary organisation, Lütge was one of many who responded by resigning from the Stahlhelm. Unlike many of the scholars who preserved their university careers through the Hitler years, Lütge never found it necessary to join [[Nazi Party |The Party]] itself.{{cite book| author=Michael Kissener|title=Ut omnes unum sint: Gründungspersönlichkeiten der Johannes-Gutenberg-Universität|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZPxxy-mWHdYC&pg=PA110|year=2005|publisher=Franz Steiner Verlag| isbn=978-3-515-08650-9|page=110}} Nevertheless, he did join the party's [[National Socialist People's Welfare |"People's Welfare" (''"Nationalsozialistische Volkswohlfahrt"'' /NSV)]] organisation in 1934. In 1937 he joined the party's [[National Socialist German Lecturers League |"Teachers' League" (''"Nationalsozialistischer Deutscher Dozentenbund, "'' / NSDDB)]]. And in 1944 he added the [[:de:Nationalsozialistischer Altherrenbund |"Altherrenbund"]], a party organisation for university academics, to his portfolio of memberships.Andreas Dornheim: Die deutsche Agrargeschichte in der NS-Zeit und die Lehrstuhl-Berufungen nach 1945 in Westdeutschland. In: Zeitschrift für Agrargeschichte und Agrarsoziologie 53 (2005), pp. 39–55 In January 1936 he received his [[habilitation]] degree from the [[University of Jena]], which opened the way to a university teaching career in respect of [[:de:Volkswirtschaftslehre |Applied economics (Volkswirtschaft)]] and [[Economic history]]. Because of the amount of relevant research work that he had already undertaken he was awarded the habilitation without any requirement to write a habilitation-dissertation. The faculty deemed the two dissertations he had already completed in respect of his doctorates sufficient. Receipt of his [[:de:Lehrberechtigung |teaching permit (''"venia legendi "'')]] was delayed till the next year due to differences with government authorities. There is speculation that he only received it at all because of his longstanding personal friendship with the nationally respected economist [[:de:Jens Jessen |Jens Jessen]] who at this stage was still a committed [[Nazi Party |party member]] (though he would later be executed by hanging). In 1937 Lütge began working as a teacher in his disciplines at the [[University of Jena|Jena University]] Law and Economics faculties. === Leipzig in the 1940s === In 1940 Lütge was offered and accepted a junior professorship in [[:de:Volkswirtschaftslehre |Applied economics (Volkswirtschaft)]], with a particular focus on [[:de:Wohnungswirtschaft |settlement and housing]] at the [[HHL Leipzig Graduate School of Management |"Handelshochschule Leipzig" (HHL / ''loosely, "Commercial academy"'')]] - as it was known at that time, in [[Leipzig]]. He had already been taking a quasi-scientific approach to the housing issues which was at the time innovative. His specialities included housing-market pricing and statistics. In 1940, the year of his appointment, he was in a position to publish a systematic introduction to [[:de:Wohnungswirtschaft |settlement and housing]], which was republished in 1949.{{cite book|author=Friedrich Lütge |title=Wohnungswirtschaft: eine systematische Darstellung unter besonderer Berücksichtigung der deutschen Wohnungswirtschaft| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DmRuAAAAIAAJ|year=1949|publisher=G. Fischer}} it can be seen as the first comprehensive [[Monograph |academic monograph]] on the subject. Karl Bosl: Friedrich Lütge 21.10.1901–25.8.1968. In: Jahrbuch der Bayerischen Akademie der Wissenschaften. 1964, pp. 202–205, He was conscripted into the [[Wehrmacht |army]] in August 1941, but was released on health grounds in May 1943 after being assessed as unsuitable for service on account of a spinal condition. He returned to the [[HHL Leipzig Graduate School of Management |Leipzig]] and was promoted to a full professorship. Jointly with [[:de:Erich Preiser |Erich Preiser]] he took on responsibility for the annual production of the [[:de:Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik |"Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik" (''loosely "Year books of National Economy and Statistics"'')]]. The compendium was banned in 1944 but returned, still produced by Lütge and Preise, in 1949.{{cite web|title=1943-1967/68: Friedrich Lütge und Erich Preiser|work=Historie der Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik |publisher=Zentrum fuer Europaeische Wirtschaftsforschung GmbH|url=ftp://ftp.zew.de/pub/zew-docs/div/historie_jb.pdf| accessdate=27 October 2018}} [[End of World War II in Europe|War ended]] in May 1945 and the western two thirds of what had been Germany was divided into four [[Allied-occupied Germany|military occupation zones]]. [[Leipzig]] had been liberated from National Socialism in April 1945 by the [[2nd Infantry Division (United States)|US]] [[69th Infantry Division (United States)|army]], but a different division of Germany had already [[Yalta Conference|been agreed]] between the [[Allied leaders of World War II|leaders]] of the victorious powers whereby Leipzig should [[Soviet Military Administration in Germany|be administered]] as part of the [[Soviet occupation zone]]. The American military commanders agreed that Friedrich Lütge, as a "non-party comrade" and a member of the [[Confessing Church|anti-Nazi Confessing church]] should be appointed post-war [[Rector (academia)|rector]] of the [[HHL Leipzig Graduate School of Management |"Hochschule für Wirtschaftswissenschaften "("Commercial academy"'')]] as it was by now known. There were additional curatorial responsibilities. When the American troops withdrew from Leipzig in July 1945 the Soviet commanders who moved in were content to confirm his appointment. In 1946 the academy was merged into the [[University of Leipzig |University]] Faculty for Economics and Social Sciences and Lütge, now on the Leipzig university payroll, was appointed dean.{{cite web |url=https://research.uni-leipzig.de/catalogus-professorum-lipsiensium/leipzig/Luetge_1066.pdf |work=Professorenkatalog der Universität Leipzig / Catalogus Professorum Lipsiensium, Herausgegeben vom Lehrstuhl für Neuere und Neueste Geschichte |publisher=Historisches Seminar der Universität Leipzig |title=Prof. Dr. rer. pol. et phil. Friedrich Lütge |accessdate=27 October 2018}} Lütge was no fan of [[Communism]]. He characterised the [[Communist Party of Germany|Communist Party]] and the [[Nazi Party|National Socialist Party]] as "warring brothers from the same root" (''"feindliche Brüder des gleichen Stammes"'')Markus Wustmann: Die Gesellschaftswissenschaftliche Fakultät in Leipzig 1947–1951. In: Ulrich von Hehl (editor-compiler): Sachsens Landesuniversität in Monarchie, Republik und Diktatur. Beiträge zur Geschichte der Universität Leipzig vom Kaiserreich bis zur Auflösung des Landes Sachsen 1952, Leipzig 2005, {{ISBN|3-374-02282-0}}, pp. 289–306 He therefore did what he could to resist state mandated appointments of party-line goal oriented Marxist professors to his faculty.{{cite book|author=Konrad Krause|title=Alma mater Lipsiensis: Geschichte der Universität Leipzig von 1409 bis zur Gegenwart|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jvlohgzMzBcC&pg=PA329|year=2003|publisher=Leipziger Universitätsverlag| isbn=978-3-936522-65-5|page=329}} That led to accusations that he was trying to block denazification and to protect Nazis. [[University of Leipzig |The university]] nominated him to take over as dean of their new social sciences faculty but the [[:de:Deutsche Verwaltung für Volksbildung |Soviet Zone administration for popular education (''"Deutsche Verwaltung für Volksbildung"'')]] then rejected the appointment because of his political stance. Before his position could become any more difficult, in September 1946 Lütge accepted a chair in political economics at the [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich]] and relocated to the US occupation zone (after May 1949 part of [[West Germany]]) to take up his new position. The Munich job also came with directorship of the Economic History Seminar that had been created at the university by [[:de:Jakob Strieder |Jakob Strieder]] back in the 1920s. === Postwar Munich === Friedrich Lütge took up his teaching chair at Munich in 1946 or 1947.. The next year his colleague [[:de:Hans Proesler |Hans Proesler]], [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich|Munich's]] Professor of Economic History, left to take up a new position [[:de:Hochschule für Wirtschafts- und Sozialwissenschaften Nürnberg |in Nuremberg]] and Lütge took on his former colleague's discipline, now in charge of both the [[:de:Volkswirtschaftslehre |Applied economics (Volkswirtschaft)]] Institute and that of the university Institute for Economic History.{{cite web|title=Stichworte zur Institutionalisierung der Wirtschaftsgeschichte in der Staatswirtschaftlichen/Volkswirtschaftlichen Fakultät der Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München |author=[[Knut Borchardt]]| url=https://www.econhist.econ.uni-muenchen.de/geschichte/wigeschmu_nchen.pdf|publisher=Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München|accessdate=27 October 2018}} Meanwhile, in the [[Soviet occupation zone]] (relaunched in October 1949 as the [[Group of Soviet Forces in Germany |Soviet sponsored]] [[German Democratic Republic |German Democratic Republic / East Germany)]]) Lütge's 1940 book, "Kriegsprobleme der Wohnungswirtschaft" was consigned to the official [[:de:Liste der auszusondernden Literatur |list of books to be weeded out (''"Liste der auszusondernden Literatur"'')]]. Alongside his duties at [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich|the university]] he also taught at the [[Technical University of Munich]] and at the city's then separate [[Bavarian School of Public Policy |"University for Politics" (''"Hochschule für Politik München"'')]]. That was the context in which his 1948 book "Einführung in die Lehre vom Gelde" (''loosely, "Introduction to the Doctrine of Money"'') appeared. He had already, while still at Leipzig, highlighted the unique nature of historical [[Manorialism|landlord and tenant relationships]] in [[Bavaria]], and in 1949 he published the resulting study under the title "Die bayerische Grundherrschaft – Untersuchungen über die Agrarverfassung Altbayerns im 16.–18. Jahrhundert." (''loosely "Bavarian Manorialism - Investigations into the agrarian constitutional structures in old Bavaria during the sixteenth, seventeenth and eighteenth centuries"'').{{cite book|author1=Peter Blickle (author)|author2=Gertrud Schröder-Lembke (editor-compiler)|title=Deutsche Agrargeschichte in der zweiten Haelfte des 20. Jahrhunderts|work=Studien zur Agrargeschichte|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aZJsDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA8|date=26 September 2016|publisher=Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co KG|isbn=978-3-11-050936-6|page=8}} In addition to these agrarian historical themes, Lütge's postwar research scope covered trade and commerce, notably in protestant [[Nuremberg]]. He also re-evaluated conventional [[Periodization |definitions of western historical periods]] through the prisms of economic and agrarian history, both in writing and in lectures, which gave rise to lively discussions between experts.Knut Borchardt: Friedrich Lütge. In: Wilhelm Abel, Knut Borchardt, Hermann Kellenbenz, Wolfgang Zorn (editor-compilers): Wirtschaft, Geschichte und Wirtschaftsgeschichte. Festschrift zum 65. Geburtstag von Friedrich Lütge. Fischer, Stuttgart 1966, pp. 1–7 In 1949 [[Deutscher Historikertag |German Historians' Day]] took place at [[Munich]] and Lütge took the opportunity to set out his thesis that the [[Black Death]] which reached Europe between 1346 and 1350, and the ensuing changes in economic and political power balances that ensued as a result of depopulation, made 1350 a much more plausible starting point for "[[Early modern period |Modern history]]" than 1500 which then (as now) was widely - often unquestioningly - identified as the starting point for the modern era in European history. The next year he set out the contention in greater detail in the newly redesigned and relaunched [[:de:Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik |"Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik" (''loosely "Year books of National Economy and Statistics"'')]].Friedrich Lütge: Das 14./15. Jahrhundert in der Sozial- und Wirtschaftsgeschichte. In: Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Geschichte. vol. 162, 1950, pp. 161–213. He challenged another historians' shibboleth in 1958 when he argued that the decades directly preceding the [[Thirty Years' War]] had not been a period of slow decline, marked by a succession of poor harvests in Europe, as widely believed, but that it was only the outbreak of hostilities in 1618 that put an end to several decades of dynamic economic development.Friedrich Lütge: Die wirtschaftliche Lage Deutschlands vor Ausbruch des Dreißigjährigen Krieges. In: Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik. vol 170, 1958, pp. 43–99. [[:de:Wohnungswirtschaft |Settlement and housing (''"Wohnungswirtschaft"'')]] was a topic that continued to interest him during his Munich years. Lütge was a member of an "Expert Advisory Committee" to the [[:de:Bundesbauministerium |West German Ministry for Housing Development]], and in 1949 published a new edition of his introduction to [[:de:Wohnungswirtschaft |settlement and housing]]. Then in 1957 he authored a further contribution under the title "Die Wohnungs- und Siedlungswirtschaft in der Konjunktur" (''loosely, "Housing and urban development and the economic cycle"'').Friedrich Lütge: Die Wohnungs- und Siedlungswirtschaft in der Konjunktur. R. Müller, Köln-Braunsfeld 1957. In 1960 he received an invitation, which in the end he turned down, to take a professorship in Economic History at the [[University of Cologne]]. This triggered a negotiation with [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich|his own university]] in [[Munich]] which led to a re-assignment of teaching responsibilities that corresponded more closely with the reality of what was already happening. At the same time his "Seminar for Economic History" was extended in scope and elevated in status, becoming the university "Institute for Social and Economic History". In 1967 he published in a single volume a synthesis from his various regional studies concerning German [[:de:Agrarverfassung |agrarian societal structures]] from the [[early middle ages]] till the [[:de:Bauernbefreiung |so-called liberation of the peasantry]] in the eighteenth/nineteenth centuries. This appeared as Volume 3 of the "Deutschen Agrargeschichte" (''"On German Agrarian History"'') series produced by [[:de:Günther Franz |Günther Franz]] (which would eventually extend to 40 volumes).{{cite book|author=Heinrich Richard Schmidt| title=Geleitwort| work=Dorf und Religion: reformierte Sittenzucht in Berner Landgemeinden der frühen Neuzeit|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nt84MvAODeoC&pg=PR8|year=1995|publisher=Lucius & Lucius DE|isbn=978-3-437-50391-7|page=8}} Back in 1952 he had already published "Deutschen Sozial- und Wirtschaftsgeschichte" (''"German Social and Economic History"'') which provides a multi-faceted overview of his entire research scope, and a widely used textbook which in some ways represents his most important contribution to historiography. New reworked editions appeared in 1960 and 1966.{{cite web |url= https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-economic-history/article/deutsche-sozialund-wirtschaftsgeschichte-by-friedrich-lutge-2nd-rev-ed-berlingottingenheidelberg-springer-verlag-1960-pp-xvi-552-dm-4860/A59FDFC02F7E682EB656507FF1190288 |title=Deutsche Sozial-und Wirtschaftsgeschichte. By Friedrich Lütge. 2nd (rev.) ed. Berlin-Göttingen-Heidelberg: Springer Verlag, 1960. Pp. xvi, 552. ("abstract")|date=March 1963|author=Herman Freudenberger |publisher=The Economic History Association & Cambridge University Press|pages=117-118|work=Reviews of books |accessdate=28 October 2018}} In 1967/68 Friedrich Lütge succeeded in obtaining funding for a second teaching chair in Economic and Social History at [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich|Munich]]. [[:de:Wolfgang Zorn |Wolfgang Zorn]] was invited to fill it.{{cite web|url=http://daten.digitale-sammlungen.de/~db/0006/bsb00064108/images/index.html?fip=193.174.98.30&seite=162&pdfseitex=|title=Nachruf: Wolfgang Zorn|work=Zeitschrift für bayerische Landesgeschichte|pages= 441-444|author=Rolf Kiessling|accessdate=28 October 2018}} Friedrich Lütge himself was by this point seriously ill. He died on 25 August 1968. He was succeeded at Munich by [[Knut Borchardt]]. == Memberships and celebration == From 1955 Friedrich Lütge was a member of the [[Bavarian Academy of Sciences and Humanities]] in [[Munich]]. In addition, in 1966 he became a corresponding member of the [[Royal Academies for Science and the Arts of Belgium]]. At the Munich academy he initiated the establishment of a commission for social and economic history, the committee of which he then chaired. On 18 February 1961 the "Gesellschaft für Sozial- und Wirtschaftsgeschichte" (GSWG - ''"Society for Social and Economic History"'') was founded. Lütge was key to its creation. Till his death he served as its first chairman.{{cite web |url=http://www.gswg.eu/Ueber-uns/ |title=Der Zweck der Gesellschaft .... Das wissenschaftliche Ziel der Gesellschaft .... Der Vorstand .... Mitglieder des Vorstands der Gesellschaft für Sozial- und Wirtschaftsgeschichte (GSWG) 1961 bis heute |work=Gesellschaft für Sozial- und Wirtschafts-geschichte e.V. |accessdate=28 October 2018}} Since 2005 the GSWG has awarded a Friedrich Lütge Prize every two years "for outstanding dissertations on Social and Economic History".{{cite web|url=http://www.gswg.eu/Luetge-Preis/|title=Friedrich-Lütge-Preis für hervorragende Dissertationen| author=Prof. Dr. Mark Spoerer, Universität Regensburg, i.A. GSWG|publisher=Gesellschaft für Sozial- und Wirtschaftsgeschichte e. V., c/o Universität Regensburg|accessdate=28 October 2018}} Lütge also headed up the Economic History committee of the [[Verein für Socialpolitik |"German Economic Association (''"Verein für Socialpolitik"'')]]" between 1958 and 1962.{{cite web |title=Über den Ausschuss |url=https://www.vfs.uni-bayreuth.de/de/ausschuss/index.html |author=Christoph Buchheim (1954-2009) |date=2006 |work=Verein für Socialpolitik – Wirtschaftshistorischer Ausschuss |publisher=Universität Bayreuth |accessdate=28 October 2018}} == Producer-editor / Publisher == In 1943 Lütge teamed up with [[:de:Günther Franz |Günther Franz]] to launch the "Quellen und Forschungen zur Agrargeschichte" (''"Sources and Research in Agrarian History"'') series at [[:de:Gustav Fischer Verlag |Gustav Fischer Verlag]]. The times were not propitious, but after the war, joined by [[Wilhelm Abel]], they made a success of the initiative. At the same publishing house Lütge launched another series, "Forschungen zur Sozial- und Wirtschaftsgeschichte" (''"Researches into Social and Economic Hostory"'') in 1959. Additionally, from the last part of 1943, together with [[:de:Erich Preiser |Erich Preiser]] he became co-producer of the annual [[:de:Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik |"Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Statistik" (''loosely "Year books of National Economy and Statistics"'')]], on which he had previously worked under the direction of [[:de:Ludwig Elster |Ludwig Elster]], securing the publication's future through a difficult period. After Preiser died in August 1967, Lütge became sole producer of it, but his illness forced him out in May 1968. He seriously considered renaming the Jahrbücher as "Jahrbücher für Nationalökonomie und Wirtschaftsgeschichte" (''loosely "Year books of National Economy and Economic History"'') in order more accurately to reflect the interdisciplinary approach taken under his stewardship, but that name change never happened. In 1953 he also became one of the co-producers of the [[:de:Zeitschrift für Agrargeschichte und Agrarsoziologie |"Zeitschrift für Agrargeschichte und Agrarsoziologie" (''"Journal for Agrarian History and Sociology"'')]].{{cite book|author1=Michael Fahlbusch|author2=Ingo Haar|author3=Alexander Pinwinkler|title=Handbuch der völkischen Wissenschaften: Akteure, Netzwerke, Forschungsprogramme|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3QE2DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA182|date=11 September 2017| publisher=De Gruyter|isbn=978-3-11-042989-3|page=182}} ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lütge, Friedrich}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1901 births]] [[Category:1968 deaths]] [[Category:People from Wernigerode]] [[Category:20th-century economists]] [[Category:Economic historians]] [[Category:Social historians]] [[Category:University of Jena faculty]] [[Category:Leipzig University faculty]] [[Category:Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich faculty]] [[Category:Members of the Bavarian Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:German National People's Party politicians]] [[Category:Sturmabteilung personnel]] [[Category:Literary editors]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox person |name = Harry Järv |image = File:Harry Järv in color.jpg |caption = Harry Järv during World War II |birth_name = Harry Järv |birth_date = {{Birth date|1921|3|27|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Korsholm]], [[Finland]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2009|12|21|1921|3|27|df=yes}} |death_place = [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] |resting_place = Korsholm old cemetery |occupation = [[librarian]], [[author]], [[translator]] |nationality = Swedish, Finnish |signature = }}
'''Harry Järv''' (27 March 1921 – 21 December 2009<ref name=hs>[http://www.hs.fi/muistot/a1364353229846 Harry Järv Obituary] (in Finnish). Retrieved 4 July 2013.</ref>) was a [[Finland Swedish]] [[librarian]], [[author]] and [[translator]]. He was a [[lieutenant]] ranked [[veteran]] of [[World War II]]. By his political views Järv was an [[Anarcho-syndicalism|anarcho-syndicalist]].
== Early years and wartime == Järv was born in a farmer's family in Western Finnish municipality of [[Korsholm]]. After graduating from high school in [[Vaasa]] Järv went to sea at the age of 18.<ref name=kap>{{cite web|url= http://www.anarkismi.net/kapis/22harry.htm |title= Suomenruotsalainen sotasankari – ja anarkisti |publisher= Kapinatyöläinen |year=1997 | language = Finnish|accessdate= 4 July 2013}}</ref> As the [[Winter War]] broke out on November 1939 he enlisted in the [[Finnish Army]] as a volunteer. Later at World War II Järv was a platoon leader in the [[61st Infantry Regiment (Finland)|61st Infantry Regiment]] that consisted almost exclusively of [[Swedish-speaking Finns]]. He was a member of [[Patrolling|patrol unit]], leading [[Reconnaissance|recon]] and combat patrols behind the enemy lines. On September 1943 Järv was seriously wounded by a [[landmine]] and he spent rest of the war at [[Saint Göran Hospital]] in [[Stockholm]].<ref name=wwII>[http://www.ww2incolor.com/finnish_forces/Lieutenant_Harry_Jarv_1941-1943.html WWII in Color – Lieutenant Harry Järv] (in English). Retrieved 4 July 2013.</ref>
Järv carried a camera through the war and took a plenty of pictures that were later published in his books. The 2004 Finnish war film ''[[Beyond the Front Line]]'' is based on Järv's diaries.<ref name=wwII/> In 1945 Järv helped his former superior [[Alpo Marttinen]] flee Finland to Sweden, although Järv said he didn't like Marttinen as a person. Colonel Marttinen, who later joined the [[United States Army]], was involved with the [[Weapons Cache Case]].<ref name=kap/>
== Later years == After the war was over, Järv received a [[scholarship]] from [[Uppsala University]] and moved to Sweden where he spent the rest of his life. Järv had a great interest in reading and collecting books since his childhood.<ref name=kap/> Järv's personal library had more than 14,000 copies.<ref name=hs/> He worked as a librarian and later as a deputy director at the [[National Library of Sweden]].
In 1973 Järv was awarded an [[Honorary degree]] by Uppsala University. He was also a member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.dn.se/kultur-noje/kunskapstorstig-jarv-laste-laxan-i-falt/ |title= Kunskapstörstig Järv läste läxan i fält |publisher= Dagens Nyheter |date= 4 March 2004 | language = Swedish|accessdate= 4 July 2013}}</ref> Järv wrote and translated more than 50 books as well as dozens of articles in various publications.<ref>[http://libris.kb.se/hitlist.jsp?q=f%C3%B6rf%3A%28J%C3%A4rv%2C+Harry%2C+1921-2009%29 Libris] (in Swedish). Retrieved 4 July 2013.</ref> His own books were mostly an [[essay]] collections of [[Ancient history]], [[politics]] and [[philosophy]]. Järv was the [[Editor-in-chief]] in Swedish culture magazines ''Horisont'', ''Radix'' and ''Fenix'' and was known as an eminent expert on [[Franz Kafka]].
== Political ideas == Järv was first introduced to anarchist ideas as a teenager by the books of [[Peter Kropotkin]]. On his time at the sea Järv was influenced by Finnish [[syndicalist]] [[Niilo Wälläri]] who was the leader of [[Finnish Seamen’s Union]]. During the war Järv suited anarchist ideas on his role as a platoon leader. Järv treated his men equally to himself and the decisions were made democratically. This often led to conflicts with his superior officers and Järv was considered as "unmilitary". In 1952 Järv joined the Swedish anarcho-syndicalist union [[Central Organisation of the Workers of Sweden|SAC]] and started writing articles in its newspaper ''[[Arbetaren]]''.<ref name=kap/>

'''Henry Joseph Frendo''' (born August 29, 1948) is a [[professor]] of [[Modern History]], teaching at the [[University of Malta]] since 1992. Frendo has previously worked with the [[UNHCR]], and was stationed in Switzerland, Mozambique, Zimbabwe, Egypt and Papua New Guinea. His main areas of research and interest are related to history since 1798; related to imperialism, nationalism, decolonization, [[postcolonialism]], journalism, migration and ethnicity - in Central and Eastern Europe, the Mediterranean and [[MENA]]. Other areas of his interest are languages, culture and statehood.
==Bibliography==
In 1970 Frendo completed his Bachelors in Maltese, English and History at the [[University of Malta]]. During the 1960s Frendo was involved in a number of Youth and Student groups. From 1968 to 1969 Frendo was Chairman of a student-led campaign called ‘Djar ghall-Maltin’ (Houses for the Maltese), which aimed to secure low-cost housing and land planning in the wake of newly achieved independence from the British. From 1970-1971 Frendo was made Editor-in-Chief of daily Maltese newspaper called Il-Hajja (The Life).
In 1973 Frendo graduated with a Masters in History from the University of Malta, with a thesis on the language-culture clash in the 19th – 20th century between traditional italianita’ – latinita’ adherents and utilitarian assimilationist pro-English supporters and the emergence of Maltese language. In the same year, Frendo became resident at University College at the University of Oxford in the United Kingdom. Frendo received his [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in Modern History from the University of Oxford in 1976. In his doctoral thesis, Frendo wrote on the formation of political parties in Malta under British rule, which was later published in his 1979 book ''Party Politics in a Fortress Colony''. Frendo later returned to Malta, between 1976-1978, to be promoted from Assistant Lecturer to Lecturer in History at the University of Malta.
In 1978 Frendo accepted a position with the [[United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees]] (UNHCR) at their Headquarters in Geneva, after he encountered fierce resistance to his academic work by the [[Malta Labour Party|Labour]] government. In 1979 Frendo was promoted to the position of Programme Officer in the Middle East and North Africa section, whilst still in Geneva. During his tenure there, Frendo was assigned to liaise in mass voluntary repatriation operations in Zimbabwe from neighbouring countries - such as Mozambique, Zambia and Botswana. In 1982 Frendo was assigned as the UNHCR’s Deputy Representative to [[Arab Republic of Egypt|Egypt]]. There Frendo was awarded indefinite appointment by [[Kofi Annan]], then serving as Chief of Personnel. From 1984 to 1985, Frendo was assigned as Head of Mission in Papua New Guinea where he was responsible for the first international assistance agreement between the UNHCR and the Papua New Guinea government.
From 1985 to 1988 Frendo was a [[Senior Lecturer]] in European political development, Commonwealth history and Ethnic Studies at La Trobe University, Victoria, Australia. At this same time, Frendo also worked as a consultant with the [[Australian National University]] in Canberra on the Australian bicentennial social encyclopaedia, and as a consultant to the Victor Ethnic Affairs Commission where he set up Victoria’s Legal Interpreting Services.
In 1988 Frendo returned to Malta where he was appointed as Associate Professor of Modern History with the University. In 1989 Frendo accepted a Fellowship with the [[University of Salzburg]], Austria. Since 1988 Frendo has been involved in extensive television, radio and journalist work. Frendo started off 1992 by being appointed a full-ranked Professor in Modern History at the University of Malta. In this same year, Frendo also appeared as a Guest Professor with the [[University of Augsburg]] in Germany lecturing in their Faculty of Philosophy and Sociology. In 1993 Frendo was appointed [[Chairman]] of the European Cultural Foundation’s Malta branch, a post which he held until 1997. From 1994-2001 Frendo served as Mayor of Attard (Malta) and as the President of the College of Mayors. In 1996 Frendo was elected a [[Life Member]] of [[Clare Hall, Cambridge|Clare Hall]] at the [[University of Cambridge]] whilst there as a visiting fellow. From 1996 to 1998, Frendo was Chairman of the [[Euro-Med Group]] and was Head of Delegation to the Congress of Local and Regional Authorities of Europe (CLRAE) for two terms.<ref>http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20040714/local/henry-frendo-short-listed-for-top-euromed-post</ref>
In the summer of 2000 Frendo received a [[Fulbright Scholarship]] to lecture at [[Loyal University in New Orleans]] (USA). In 2001 Frendo became the [[Vice-President]] of the CLRAE. In this same year, Frendo was appointed as the Maltese Ministry of Justice and Home Affairs’ Chairman of the Refugee Appeals Board in Valletta (Malta). In 2002 Frendo became a [[Visiting Professor]] at [[Indiana State University]] (USA). Frendo is also [[Executive director|Director]] of the Malta University Broadcasting Services Limited, where he also serves as [[Co-Editor]] of the Journal of Mediterranean Studies, Editor of the Maltese History journal ‘Storja’ and is[[Vice-President]] of the University of Malta’s History Society.
Since 2005 he was involved with the Centre of European Policy Studies 5-year Challenge programme on ‘Freedom and Security’. In 2006 Frendo was appointed Guest Professor at the [[University of Enna]] (Italy) where he lectured in contemporary History and Politics of the Mediterranean. Frendo was the convenor of two international conferences on Migration, asylum and security: the Eastern and Southern border experiences; and The European Mind: Narrative and Identity for the International Society for the Study of European Ideas.
He is fluent Arabic, English, French, Italian and Maltese.

__NOTOC__ {{Other uses|Interview (disambiguation)}} [[File:Sara Prigan (41497467772).jpg|thumb|A musician interviewed in a radio studio]] [[File:Job interview.jpg|thumb|A woman interviewing for a job]] [[File:10944 Ειρήνη και Άννα Βασιλείου.jpg|thumb|Athletes interviewed after a race]] [[File:Luis Castro esklevndurt.jpg|thumb|Some interviews are recorded for television broadcast]] [[File:Videoconferencing via Skype across the Internet between Interview Coach Mark Efinger and a woman being coached.png|thumb|right|Modern videoconferencing such as [[Skype]] over the Internet allows an interview coach to assist a young woman before a hypothetical [[college interview]] despite the distance.]] An '''interview''' is a [[conversation]] where [[question]]s are asked and answers are given.<ref name=twsMerriam>Merriam Webster Dictionary, [http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/interview Interview], Dictionary definition, Retrieved February 16, 2016</ref> In common parlance, the word "interview" refers to a one-on-one conversation between an ''interviewer'' and an ''interviewee''. The interviewer asks questions to which the interviewee responds, usually so information may be transferred from interviewee to interviewer (and any other audience of the interview). Sometimes, information can be transferred in both directions. [[communication]], unlike a speech, which produces a one-way flow of information.
Interviews usually take place [[Face-to-face interaction|face to face]] and in person, although modern communications technologies such as the [[Internet]] have enabled conversations to happen in which parties are separated geographically, such as with [[videoconferencing]] software,<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.brandeis.edu/hiatt/howto/interview/index.html |title= Introduction to Interviewing |publisher= [[Brandeis University]] |accessdate= 2015-05-02}}</ref> and [[telephone interview]]s can happen without visual contact. Interviews almost always involve [[speech|spoken conversation]] between two or more parties, although in some instances a "conversation" can happen between two persons who type questions and answers back and forth. Interviews can range from [[Unstructured interview|unstructured]] or free-wheeling and open-ended conversations in which there is no predetermined plan with prearranged questions,<ref>{{cite book|last1= Rogers|first1= Carl R.|title= Frontier Thinking in Guidance|date= 1945|publisher= Science research associates|location= University of California|pages= 105–112|url= https://books.google.com/?id=3OdBAAAAIAAJ&dq=frontiers+of+guidance+Non-directive+counselling+as+an+effective+technique&q=Non-directive+counselling+as+an+effective+technique|accessdate= March 18, 2015}}</ref> to highly [[structured interview|structured]] conversations in which specific questions occur in a specified order.<ref>[http://www.sagepub.com/booksProdDesc.nav?prodId=Book226668 Kvale & Brinkman. 2008. InterViews, 2nd Edition. Thousand Oaks: SAGE.] {{ISBN|978-0-7619-2542-2}}</ref> They can follow diverse formats; for example, in a [[ladder interview]], a respondent's answers typically guide subsequent interviews, with the object being to explore a respondent's [[subconscious]] [[Motivation|motives]].<ref>2009, Uxmatters, [http://www.uxmatters.com/mt/archives/2009/07/laddering-a-research-interview-technique-for-uncovering-core-values.php Laddering: A research interview technique for uncovering core values]</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=15 Tips on How to Nail a Face-to-Face Interview |url=https://blog.pluralsight.com/15-tips-on-how-to-nail-a-face-to-face-interview |website=blog.pluralsight.com |accessdate=2015-11-05}}</ref> Typically the interviewer has some way of recording the information that is gleaned from the interviewee, often by writing with a pencil and paper, sometimes transcribing with a [[Digital video recorder|video]] or [[Sound recording and reproduction|audio]] recorder, depending on the context and extent of information and the length of the interview. Interviews have a duration in time, in the sense that the interview has a beginning and an ending.
The traditional two-person interview format, sometimes called a one-on-one interview, permits direct questions and followups, which enables an interviewer to better gauge the accuracy of responses. It is a flexible arrangement in the sense that subsequent questions can be tailored to clarify earlier answers. Further, it eliminates any possible distortion by having third parties present.
Face to face interviewing makes it easier for people to interact and form a connection, and it helps both the potential employer and potential hire who they might be interacting with.<ref name=SS1> Snap Surveys, [https://www.snapsurveys.com/blog/advantages-disadvantages-facetoface-data-collection/ Advantages and disadvantages of face to face data collection], Retrieved April 27, 2018</ref> Further, face to face interview sessions can be more enjoyable.<ref name=SS1/>
== Contexts == Interviews can happen in a wide variety of contexts:
'''Employment'''. Interviews in an employment context are typically called [[job interview]]s which describe a formal consultation for the purpose of evaluating the qualifications of the interviewee for a specific position.<ref name = "Dipboye et al">Dipboye, R. L., Macan, T., & Shahani-Denning, C. (2012). The selection interview from the interviewer and applicant perspectives: Can't have one without the other. In N. Schmitt (Ed.), The Oxford handbook of personnel assessment and selection (pp. 323-352). New York City: Oxford University.</ref> Interviews are seen as a useful tool in assessing qualifications.<ref name=Chron>{{cite web|url=http://work.chron.com/value-importance-job-interview-1660.html |title=The Value or Importance of a Job Interview |publisher=[[Houston Chronicle]] |accessdate=2014-01-17}}</ref> A specific type of job interview is a [[case interview]] in which the applicant is presented with a question or task or challenge, and asked to resolve the situation.<ref>Maggie Lu, ''The Harvard Business School Guide to Careers in Management Consulting'', 2002, page 21, {{ISBN|978-1-57851-581-3}}</ref> Sometimes to prepare for job interviews, candidates are treated to a [[mock interview]] as a training exercise to prepare the respondent to handle questions in the subsequent 'real' interview. Sometimes the interviews happen in several waves, with the first interview sometimes being called a ''screening interview'' which is a shorter length interview, followed by more in-depth interviews later on, usually by company personnel who can ultimately hire the applicant. Technology has enabled new possibilities for interviewing; for example, video phoning technology has enabled applicants to interview for jobs despite being in different cities or countries than the interviewer.
'''Psychology'''. Psychologists use a variety of interviewing methods and techniques to try to understand and help their patients. In a [[psychiatric interview]], a psychiatrist or psychologist or nurse asks a battery of questions to complete what is called a [[psychiatric assessment]]. Sometimes two people are interviewed by an interviewer, with one format being called [[couple interview]]s.<ref name="P-G-2015">{{cite journal |last1=Polak |first1=L |last2= Green |first2= J |year= 2015|title=Using Joint Interviews to Add Analytic Value |journal=[[Qualitative Health Research]] |volume=26|issue= 12|pages=1638|publisher= |doi= 10.1177/1049732315580103 }}</ref> Criminologists and detectives sometimes use [[cognitive interview]]s on eyewitnesses and victims to try to ascertain what can be recalled specifically from a crime scene, hopefully before the specific memories begin to fade in the mind.<ref name = "Memon,Cronin,Eaves,Bull">Memon, A., Cronin, O., Eaves, R., Bull, R. (1995). An empirical test of mnemonic components of the cognitive interview. In G. Davies, S. Lloyd-Bostock, M. McMurran, C. Wilson (Eds.), Psychology, Law, and Criminal Justice (pp. 135-145). Berlin: Walter de Gruyer.</ref><ref>Rand Corporation. (1975) The criminal investigation process (Vol. 1-3). Rand Corporation Technical Report R-1776-DOJ, R-1777-DOJ, Santa Monica, CA</ref>
'''Research'''. In [[marketing research]] and [[academic research]], interviews are used in a wide variety of ways. [[Interview (research)|Interviews]] are often used in [[qualitative research]] in which firms try to understand how consumers think. Consumer research firms sometimes use [[computer-assisted telephone interviewing]] to randomly dial phone numbers to conduct highly structured telephone interviews, with scripted questions and responses entered directly into the computer.<ref name="uslabor">{{cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/bls/glossary.htm|title=BLS Information |date=February 28, 2008|work=Glossary|publisher=U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics Division of Information Services |accessdate=2009-05-05}}</ref>
'''Journalism and other media'''. Typically, reporters covering a story in [[journalism]] conduct [[Interview (journalism)|interviews]] over the phone and in person to gain information for subsequent publication. Reporters can interview political candidates on television shows. In a [[talk show]], a radio or television "host" interviews one or more people, with the choice of topic usually being chosen by the host, sometimes for the purposes of [[entertainment]], sometimes for informational purposes. Such interviews are often recorded and some of them can be released on an [[interview disc]].
'''Other situations'''. Sometimes college representatives or alumni conduct [[college interview]]s with prospective students as a way of assessing a student's suitability while offering the student a chance to learn more about a college.<ref name="twsBostonGlobe4"/> Some services specialize in coaching people for interviews.<ref name="twsBostonGlobe4">{{cite web | author= Sanjay Salomon | date= January 30, 2015 | publisher= Boston Globe | url= http://www.boston.com/jobs/news/2015/01/30/can-failure-resume-help-you-succeed/uTBdq9A7LfXXF7vVOlG9oM/story.html | title= Can a Failure Resume Help You Succeed? | accessdate= January 31, 2016 | quote=...A 'failure resume' is ... a private exercise ... outline what they learned from the experience ... Mark Efinger is president and founder of Interview Skill Coaching Academy in Great Barrington, where he prepares candidates for the job interview experience. ... }} </ref> Embassy officials may conduct interviews with applicants for student visas before approving their visa applications.

'''Jennifer Guglielmo''' is a [[List of Italian American Women Writers|writer]], historian and associate professor at [[Smith College]],<ref name=Associate>[http://smith.edu/history/faculty_guglielmo.php History Faculty, Jennifer Guglielmo.]</ref> specializing in the histories of labor, race, women, im/migration, transnational cultures and activisms, and revolutionary social movements in the modern United States. She has published on a range of topics, including working-class feminisms, anarchism, whiteness and the Italian diaspora.
Guglielmo is the author of the award-winning book ''Living the Revolution: Italian Women's Resistance and Radicalism in New York City, 1880-1945'' (2010)<ref name=Guglielmo>Jennifer Guglielmo, ''Living the Revolution: Italian Women's Resistance and Radicalism in New York City, 1880-1945.'' Chapel Hill: [[University of North Carolina Press]] (Gender and American Culture Series), 2010.</ref> and co-editor (with Salvatore Salerno) of ''Are Italians White? How Race Is Made in America'' (2003).<ref name=GuglielmoTwo>Jennifer Guglielmo, ''Are Italians White? How Race Is Made in America.'' New York: [[Routledge]], 2003.</ref> The book was translated into Italian in 2006: ''Gli Italiani Sono Bianchi? Come l' America ha costruito la razza.''.<ref name=GuglielmoThree>Jennifer Guglielmo, ''Gli Italiani Sono Bianchi? Come l'America ha costruito la razza.'' Milan: Il Saggiatore Press, 2006.</ref> She is currently translating short essays written in Italian by immigrant women [[Anarcha-feminism|anarchists]]—such as [[Maria Roda]] and [[Virgilia D'Andrea]]—in early twentieth-century New York City and northeastern New Jersey.<ref name=Gold>Susannah Gold, [http://www.i-italy.org/15577/italian-working-class-women-us-start-20th-century "Italian Working-Class Women in the US at the Start of the 20th Century."] i-Italy.org, October 5, 2010.</ref> These will be reprinted in her next book, ''My Rebellious Heart: Immigrant Women's Anarchist Feminist Prose in New York City's Radical Subculture, 1890-1930.''
Guglielmo is also currently engaged in a grant-funded, collaborative, community-based public history/digital humanities project with the [[National Domestic Workers Alliance]]. Together they are developing tools for domestic workers and organizers to access historical knowledge and archival evidence and use history as an organizing tool.
==Life & Family== Jennifer Guglielmo was born in Flushing, NY. Her brother [[Thomas A. Guglielmo]] is also a [[historian]] and Associate Professor of American Studies<ref>[http://departments.columbian.gwu.edu/americanstudies/people/148 The Department of American Studies, Thomas A. Guglielmo.]</ref> at [[George Washington University]]. Her brother Mark Vesuvio Guglielmo is a visual artist, music producer, and rapper/emcee.<ref>[https://markguglielmo.com/about/ markguglielmo.com]</ref>
==Education & Career== Guglielmo received a Bachelor of Arts in History and Women's Studies from [[University of Wisconsin-Madison]] in 1990, a Masters of Arts in History from [[University of New Mexico]] in 1995 and a PhD in History from [[University of Minnesota]] in 2003. Her doctoral dissertation, “Negotiating Gender, Race and Coalition: Italian Women and Working-Class Politics in New York City, 1880 to 1945” won the Best Dissertation Award<ref name=Best>[http://www.ihrc.umn.edu/whoweare/newsJul19-04.php Jennifer Guglielmo wins Best Dissertation Award.]</ref> from the [[University of Minnesota]] and the [[Organization of American Historians]]’ Lerner-Scott Prize<ref name=Lerner>[http://www.oah.org/awards/awards.lernerscott.winners.html Lerner-Scott Winners], 2004.</ref> for best doctoral dissertation in U.S. women’s history.
She taught History and Women's Studies at [[William Paterson University]], [[SUNY New Paltz]], [[Ulster County Community College]], and the [[University of Minnesota]], before joining the faculty at [[Smith College]] in 2003.
==Honors & Awards== *[[Smith College]] Sherrerd Prize for Distinguished Teaching, 2012.<ref name=Sherrerd>[http://www.smith.edu/events/sherrerd_2012.php 2012 Recipients.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120520111822/http://www.smith.edu/events/sherrerd_2012.php |date=2012-05-20 }}</ref> *Helen and [[Howard R. Marraro]] Book Award<ref name=MarraroOne>[http://www.historians.org/prizes/index.cfm?PrizeAbbrev=Marraro The Helen & Howard R. Marraro Prize]</ref> for ''Living the Revolution,'' 2011.<ref name=Marraro>Helen and Howard R. Marraro Book Award, [http://www.italianhistoricalstudies.org/marraro.html List of Recipients], Society for Italian Historical Studies and the American Historical Association, 2011.</ref> *[[Theodore Saloutos]] Memorial Award for Best Book in U.S. Immigration History, ''Living the Revolution,'' 2010.<ref name=Theodore>Immigration and Ethnic History Society, [http://www.iehs.org/awards_winners.php?PHPSESSID=581b6ea95a4e47f6ea91dfca0d35fdfe 2010 Theodore Saloutos Memorial Award Winners], 2010.</ref> *Honorable Mention from the [[Berkshire Conference of Women Historians]]<ref name=Berk>[http://berksconference.org Berkshire Conference of Women Historians.]</ref> for Best First Book, ''Living the Revolution,'' 2010.<ref name=Berkshire>Berkshire Conference of Women Historians, [http://berksconference.org/prizes-and-awards/2010-winners-of-the-berks-book-and-article-prizes Jennifer Guglielmo's ''Living the Revolution,'' Honorable Mention Best First Book], 2010.</ref> *[[Organization of American Historians]] Lerner-Scott Prize for the Best Doctoral Dissertation in U.S. Women's History, 2004.<ref name="Lerner"/> *[[University of Minnesota]] Best Dissertation Award for "Negotiating Gender, Race and Coalition: Italian Women and Working Politics in New York City, 1880 to 1945,” 2003.<ref name="Best"/>
==Grants & Fellowships== In 2018, Guglielmo received a private grant of over $1 million for a two-year public history/worker education project (2018-2020) with the [[National Domestic Workers Alliance]]. Her work has also been funded by the [[Social Science Research Council]] and the [[American Association of University Women]].

'''Johan Nicolay Tønnessen''' (30 November 1901 – 27 December 1987) was a Norwegian historian and schoolteacher.
He was born in [[Kristiansand]] as a son of port magistrate Joh. E. Tønnessen and Ida, née Stray. He [[examen artium|finished]] his secondary education in 1920 and took the [[cand.philol.]] degree at the [[University of Oslo|Royal Frederick University]] in 1928, majoring in history and minoring in French and Latin. He also took [[pedagogy]] in 1926 and was a substitute at Trondhjem Cathedral School from 1927 to 1928. In 1928 he married Lulla Evensen; they had two daughters and one son.<ref name=filo>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Tønnessen, Johan Nicolay|encyclopedia=Norges filologer og realister|edition=2nd|year=1950|language=Norwegian|page=888}}</ref>
He was a teacher at [[Gjøvik Upper Secondary School]] from 1928 to 1935 and [[Grefsen Upper Secondary School]] from 1935 to 1959.<ref name=filo/><ref name=snl/> In Gjøvik he was elected to the city council in the [[Norwegian local elections, 1934]]. He represented the Fascist party [[Nasjonal Samling]], which with 10.9% of the vote had its third most successful city election in Gjøvik. Moving to Oslo, he did not finish the term.<ref name=g150>{{cite book|last1=Ruud|first1=Marit Ekne|last2=Nygård|first2=Trond|title=Vilje til vekst|series=Gjøvik 150 år|volume=1st|year=2010|publisher=Alfa|location=Gjøvik|language=Norwegian|isbn=978-82-92253-35-9|page=302}}</ref> He became a member of the school board and deputy member of the [[municipal council (Norway)|municipal council]] of [[Aker, Norway|Aker]].<ref name=filo/>
During the [[occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany]], when Nasjonal Samling was actually propelled to power as a collaborationist party, Tønnessen was arrested by the authorities in August 1943 for resistance work. He was imprisoned in [[Bredtveit concentration camp]] until November, then in [[Møllergata 19]], then from April to October 1944 at [[Akershus Fortress]], and ultimately in [[Grini concentration camp]] until the war's end.<ref>{{cite book|editor=[[Kristian Ottosen|Ottosen, Kristian]]|title=Nordmenn i fangenskap 1940–1945|edition=1st|year=1995|publisher=Universitetsforlaget|location=Oslo|language=Norwegian|isbn=82-15-00288-9|page=640}}</ref>
Tønnessen later took the [[dr.philos.]] degree in history, and issued the books ''Ole Nielsen (Aalgaard) og hans slekt'' (1953), ''Kaperfart og skipsfart 1807–1814'' (1955), ''Porsgrunns historie'' (two volumes in 1956 and 1957). He contributed to ''Den norske sjøfarts historie'' (1951), ''Den moderne hvalfangst historie'' (1968–1970) and the third volume of ''Kristiansands historie'' (1974). His specialties were shipping, [[privateering]], [[whaling]] and town history.<ref name=snl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Johan Nicolay Tønnessen|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor=|publisher=|location=|url=http://snl.no/Johan_Nicolay_T%C3%B8nnessen|language=Norwegian|accessdate=19 January 2015}}</ref>

'''John Hobson Mathews''' (1858-1914) was a Roman Catholic Historian, Archivist and Solicitor.
He was born in Croydon to Emma Hobson from Great Grimsby and his father from St. Ives. He attended schools in [[Blackheath, London|Blackheath]] and [[Cambridge]] and worked in Malta for a short period with a shipping firm. Mathews joined the Roman Catholic church in 1877 and became a solicitor in 1889, subsequently working in Cardiff. As a keen linguist, he edited ''Emynau Catholig'' (English: 'Catholic Hymns'), translated ''Ffordd y Groes'' ('The way of the cross') and joined the Welsh Bardic Gorsedd. Mathews also edited the ''Cardiff Records, being materials for a history of the County Borough from the earliest times'' (1898-1911) and wrote a report on the Monmouthshire County Council records in 1905. He was involved in the transactions of the Cardiff Naturalists Society and, more significantly, the [[Catholic Record Society]], being among the original members of this society.
Mathews understood [[Maltese language|Maltese]], [[Cornish language|Cornish]] and [[Welsh language|Welsh]]. He married Alice Mary Gwyn-Hughes in 1892, who bore him four sons and two daughters.
He died on 30 January 1914 in Ealing.
== Other Notable Works == ''A History of the parishes of St. Ives, Lelant, Towednack, and Zennor'' (London, 1892) - published by Mathews
Martin Cock's ''Guide to St. Ives'' (St. Ives, 1906) - Edited by Mathews
''Yr Hen grefydd a'r grefydd newydd. Sef dadl … am yr Eglwys Gatholig … Wedi ei gyfieithu i'r Gymraeg gan … J. H. Jones'' (Cardiff, 1889) - Prepared by Mathews
''The Life and Memorials of Saint Teilo'' (Preston, 1893) - Prepared by Mathews
''The Vaughans of Courtfield: a study in Welsh genealogy'' (London, 1912) - based on Mathews' findings
== See also == * ''The Tablet a weekly newspaper and review'', London, 31 Jan. 1914 * ''Handlist of Manuscripts in the National Library of Wales'', 1940 * ''Cardiff Naturalists' Society: Report and Transactions'', xxxiii.

[[File:Julia Hillner Photo.jpg|thumb|Prof. Julia Hillner]] {{Infobox academic|honorific_prefix=|name=Julia Hillner|honorific_suffix=|birth_date=|birth_place=|death_date=|death_place=|nationality=German|spouse=|parents=|alma_mater=[[University of Bonn]], [[University of Perugia]], [[University of Padova]]|thesis_title=|discipline=[[Classics]], [[Late antiquity]]|workplaces=[[University of Sheffield]]|notable_works=}}
'''Julia Hillner''' is Professor of Medieval History at the [[University of Sheffield]]. She is known in particular for her work on [[late antiquity]] and her application of digital methods of [[social network analysis]] to large data sets drawn from a wide variety of late antique and early medieval sources.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/history/staff/julia-hillner#tab00|title=Hillner, Julia - Staff - History - The University of Sheffield|last=Sheffield|first=University of|website=www.sheffield.ac.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref>
== Career == Hillner studied for her [[Staatsexamen]] and PhD at the [[University of Bonn]]. She completed her PhD in 2001, which included a one-year visiting doctoral fellowship at the University of Padova (1997-8).<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/jedes-haus-ist-eine-stadt-privatimmobilien-im-spatantiken-rom/oclc/57066908|title=Jedes Haus ist eine Stadt: Privatimmobilien im spätantiken Rom|last=Hillner|first=Julia|date=2004|publisher=R. Habelt|isbn=3774932220|location=Bonn|language=German}}</ref> Her revised doctoral thesis was published in 2004 as ''Jedes Haus ist eine Stadt : Privatimmobilien im spätantiken Rom.''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bonnus.ulb.uni-bonn.de/SummonRecord/FETCH-theeuropeanlibrary_primary_20000198431360|title=Description: Jedes Haus ist eine Stadt (Julia. Hillner)|website=bonnus.ulb.uni-bonn.de|language=en|access-date=2018-09-04}}</ref>
From 1999 Hillner worked on the [[Arts and Humanities Research Council]] project ''Religion, Dynasty and Patronage in Rome, c. 440-840'' at the [[University of Manchester]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://discover.ukdataservice.ac.uk/catalogue/?sn=4630|title=Discover - Religion, Dynasty and Patronage in Rome, c.440-840|website=discover.ukdataservice.ac.uk|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref> She became a teaching fellow in Early Christianity and was a [[British Academy]] Postdoctoral Fellow from 2003 to 2008 working on ''Imprisonment in Late Antiquity: Christian Memory and Social Reality''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.britac.ac.uk/sites/default/files/ba-review07.pdf|title=British Academy Review (Issue 7 2003)|last=|first=|date=2003|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Cooper|first=Kate|title=Introduction|date=September 2007|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/religion-dynasty-and-patronage-in-early-christian-rome-300900/introduction/FFE69A57C87973B60EE37FD9D44238F1|work=Religion, Dynasty, and Patronage in Early Christian Rome, 300–900|pages=1–18|publisher=Cambridge University Press|language=en|doi=10.1017/CBO9780511482731.001|isbn=9780511482731|access-date=2018-08-20|last2=Hillner|first2=Julia}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Religion_Dynasty_and_Patronage_in_Early.html?id=p1RkQgAACAAJ&source=kp_author_description&redir_esc=y|title=Religion, Dynasty, and Patronage in Early Christian Rome, 300-900|last=Cooper|first=Kate|last2=Hillner|first2=Julia|date=2010-02-11|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521131278|language=en}}</ref> Hillner moved to the [[University of Sheffield]] in 2008.<ref name=":0" />
Hillner's work on imprisonment in late antiquity resulted in her publication ''Prison, Punishment and Penance in Late Antiquity'' (Cambridge University Press, 2015) which won an Honorable Mention at the 2016 PROSE Awards.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://proseawards.com/winners/2016-award-winners/#body|title=2016 Award Winners - PROSE Awards|work=PROSE Awards|access-date=2018-08-20|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://history.dept.shef.ac.uk/tag/julia-hillner/|title=Julia Hillner {{!}} The Department of History|website=history.dept.shef.ac.uk|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref>
From 2014 to 2017 Hillner was the Principal Investigator of ''The Migration of Faith: Clerical Exile in Late Antiquity'', an [[Arts and Humanities Research Council]] funded project in collaboration with the Digital Humanities Institute at the [[University of Sheffield]], the Faculty of Theology at the [[Martin Luther University of Halle-Wittenberg|University of Halle]], the Department of Culture and Society at [[Aarhus University]], the Abteilung Byzanzforschung at the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]], and the [[German Historical Institute London|German Historical Institute]] in London.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gtr.ukri.org/projects?ref=AH%2FL006812%2F1|title=The Migration of Faith: Clerical Exile in Late Antiquity (325-c.600AD)|last=|first=|date=|website=UK Research and Innovation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dhi.ac.uk/sites/clericalexile/people/staff/|title=Staff|date=2014-09-23|work=The Migration of Faith|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dhi.ac.uk/projects/clerical-exile-in-late-antiquity/|title=Clerical Exile in Late Antiquity|date=2014-10-07|work=DHI|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en-US}}</ref> This innovative project examined the banishment of Christian clerics across the Mediterranean during the religious controversies of [[late antiquity]] and how this shaped the institution of the Christian church. It constructed an online [[Prosopography|prosopographical]] database of exiled clerics from a wide variety of source material including contemporary [[epigraphy]], histories, [[hagiography]], and letters.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dhi.ac.uk/sites/clericalexile/resources/database/|title=Database|date=2014-10-03|work=The Migration of Faith|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en-GB}}</ref> The project also resulted in the publication of a number of books and articles on the subject,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dhi.ac.uk/sites/clericalexile/resources/books-and-articles/|title=Books and articles|date=2014-10-03|work=The Migration of Faith|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en-GB}}</ref> including an edited volume ''Clerical Exile in Late Antiquity,'' the publication of the ''XVII International Conference on Patristic Studies'' held at the [[University of Oxford]] in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pure.au.dk/portal/en/publications/clerical-exile-in-late-antiquity(f375034a-9174-4825-9302-f7e93ad25c4e).html|title=Clerical Exile in Late Antiquity - Research - Aarhus University|website=pure.au.dk|language=en|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|date=2016-09-15|editor-last=Hillner|editor-first=Julia|editor2-last=Ulrich|editor2-first=Jörg|editor3-last=Engberg|editor3-first=Jakob|title=Clerical Exile in Late Antiquity|url=https://www.peterlang.com/view/title/18490|language=en|doi=10.3726/978-3-653-06051-5}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oxfordpatristics.com/|title=patristics|website=patristics|language=en|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref>
In 2018, Hillner started a new project funded by the [[Leverhulme Trust]] on ''Women, Conflict and Peace: Gendered Networks in Early Medieval Narratives (c. 330-735).''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.leverhulme.ac.uk/sites/default/files/RPG%20March%202018_v4.pdf|title=Leverhulme Trust Research Project Grants 2018|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 August 2018}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/faculty/arts-and-humanities/ahfnews/women-conflict-peace-gendered-networks-in-early-medieval-narratives-1.774851|title=Leverhulme Trust project grant for a project entitled 'Women, Conflict and Peace: Gendered Networks in Early Medieval Narratives' - News - Faculty of Arts and Humanities - Faculties - The University of Sheffield|last=Sheffield|first=University of|website=www.sheffield.ac.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-08-20}}</ref> The project will run from 2018 to 2020 and focuses on how women and their networks fitted into the narrative of conflict and peace during the turbulent period of the 4th to 8th centuries. Hillner's work will again use digital methods of network analysis to focus on the social roles of women rather than studying individuals and will use material from a wide variety of late antique and early medieval sources.<ref name=":1" />
Hillner is also under contract with Oxford University Press to write a biography of [[Helena (empress)|Helena]], mother of the emperor [[Constantine the Great|Constantine]] for the Women in Antiquity series.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/content/series/w/women-in-antiquity-wia/?cc=gb&lang=en&|title=Women in Antiquity - Oxford University Press|website=global.oup.com|language=en|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref> The book is planned to examine Helena in the context of a network of female contacts and the social parameters of late antique women. Hillner writes a blog dedicated to the subject of Helena and her life called ''Writing Helena''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://writinghelena.wordpress.com/|title=Writing Helena|website=Writing Helena|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-22}}</ref>
Hillner is a Director of the Medieval and Ancient Research Centre at the University of Sheffield (MARCUS)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://marcus.group.shef.ac.uk/members/|title=Members|date=2014-09-02|work=MARCUS|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en-US}}</ref> and member of the Faculty of Archaeology, History and Letters of the [[British School at Rome]] (2017-2021).<ref name=":0" /> She is a member of the editorial board for the Journal of Roman Studies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-roman-studies/information/editorial-board|title=Editorial board|website=Cambridge Core|language=en|access-date=2018-11-01}}</ref>
Hillner lectured on "Empresses, Bishops and Exile in Late Antiquity: A Quantitative Approach" on the 4th April 2018 at [[Ohio State University]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://history.osu.edu/events/empresses-bishops-exile-late-antiquity-quantitative-approach|title="Empresses, Bishops and Exile in Late Antiquity: A Quantitative Approach," Julia Hillner, Sheffield University|date=2018-03-08|work=Department of History|access-date=2018-08-22|language=en}}</ref>
[[File:Cover image of Religion, Dynasty, and Patronage in Early Christian Rome, 300-900, edited by Kate Cooper and Julia Hillner.jpg|thumb|Cover image of Religion, Dynasty, and Patronage in Early Christian Rome, 300-900, edited by Kate Cooper and Julia Hillner]]
== Selected publications ==
* 'Domus, Family, and Inheritance: the Senatorial Family House in Late Antique Rome.' ''Journal of Roman Studies'' 93 (2003): 129–45.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hillner|first=Julia|date=2003|title=Domus, Family, and Inheritance: the Senatorial Family House in Late Antique Rome*|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-roman-studies/article/domus-family-and-inheritance-the-senatorial-family-house-in-late-antique-rome/960AF02708F58B40228A182070A8EF44|journal=The Journal of Roman Studies|language=en|volume=93|pages=129–145|doi=10.2307/3184642|issn=1753-528X|via=}}</ref> *''Jedes Haus ist eine Stadt: Privatimmobilien im spätantiken Rom.'' Bonn, R. Habelt. 2004.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xeq4AAAAIAAJ&q=Jedes+Haus+ist+eine+Stadt:+Privatimmobilien+im+sp%C3%A4tantiken+Rom&dq=Jedes+Haus+ist+eine+Stadt:+Privatimmobilien+im+sp%C3%A4tantiken+Rom&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjr2uuO7cndAhXIKsAKHd0zCrcQ6AEIKTAA|title=Jedes Haus ist eine Stadt: Privatimmobilien im spätantiken Rom|last=Hillner|first=Julia|date=2004|publisher=R. Habelt|language=de}}</ref> *'Clerics, property and patronage: the case of the Roman titular churches.' ''Antiquité Tardive'' 14 (2006): 59-68.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hillner|first=Julia|date=2006|title=Clerics, property and patronage: the case of the Roman titular churches|url=https://doi.org/10.1484/J.AT.2.302421|journal=Antiquité Tardive|language=en|volume=14|pages=59–68|doi=10.1484/j.at.2.302421|issn=1250-7334|via=}}</ref> * ed. with [[Kate Cooper]]. ''Religion, Dynasty, and Patronage in Early Christian Rome, 300-900.'' {{refimprove|date=May 2014}} [[File:Bhintuna bunting.jpg|thumb|New Year's Day bunting in Kathmandu.]] [[File:Halimali grain art.jpg|thumb|Halimali display, grain art showing auspicious jar on [[Kartik Poornima|Kārtik Purnimā]].]] '''Kachhalā''' ([[Nepal Bhasa]]: कछला) is the first month in the [[Nepal Era]] calendar, the national [[lunar calendar]] of [[Nepal]].{{cite news|title=Nepal Sambat gets national status |url=http://www.gorkhapatra.org.np/detail.php?article_id=8874&cat_id=5 |accessdate=8 May 2014 |newspaper=The Rising Nepal |date=24 October 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020104054/http://www.gorkhapatra.org.np/detail.php?article_id=8874&cat_id=5 |archivedate=20 October 2013 |df= }} The month corresponds to [[Kartika (month)|Kārtik]] in the [[Hindu lunar calendar]] and roughly matches [[November]] in the [[Gregorian calendar]]. Kachhalā begins with the [[new moon]] and the [[full moon]] falls on the 15th of the [[lunar month]]. The month is divided into the bright and dark fortnights which are known as Kachhalā Thwa (कछला थ्व) and Kachhalā Gā (कछला गा) respectively. The most important festival that occurs during this month is [[Tihar (festival)|Tihar]] ([[Swanti (festival)|Swanti]]). The first day of the bright fortnight of Kachhalā is New Year's Day when [[Newar]]s observe [[Mha Puja]], an auspicious ceremony to invoke good fortune during the coming year.{{cite news|title=Mha Puja today, Nepal Sambat 1132 being observed|url=http://www.ekantipur.com/2011/10/27/top-story/mha-puja-today-nepal-sambat-1132-being-observed/342845.html|accessdate=8 May 2014|newspaper=Ekantipur|date=27 October 2011}} The full moon [[Kartik Poornima|Kārtik Purnimā]] is also a major religious holiday. In [[Nepal Mandala]], the day is celebrated as Saki Milā Punhi (सकि मिला पुन्हि) or Saki Manā Punhi (सकि मना पुन्हि). Sacred paintings known as Halimali, which are made of popcorn, wheat and black soybeans, are displayed in front of temples to mark the end of the month-long hymn singing season. The special food of the day is boiled arum and sweet potato.{{cite book |last= Levy |first= Robert Isaac |date=1990 |title= Mesocosm: Hinduism and the Organization of a Traditional Newar City in Nepal|chapter=A Catalogue of Annual Events and Their Distribution throughout the Lunar Year |publisher= University of California Press |page=643 |isbn=9780520069114}} == Days in the month == {| class="wikitable" |- ! [[File:Karl Marx memorial.jpg|thumb|[[Karl Marx Monument]] in Chemnitz, commissioned in 1953 (erected 1971) with renaming of the city to Karl-Marx-Stadt.]] '''Karl Marx Year''' ({{lang-de|Karl-Marx-Jahr}}) was a series of [[Anniversary|anniversaries]] of [[Karl Marx]] commemorated by [[East Germany]] in 1953, 1968, and 1983.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3VcTAQAAMAAJ|title=Tel Aviver Jahrbuch für deutsche Geschichte|last=|first=|date=1990|publisher=Universität Tel Aviv, Fakultät für Geisteswissenschaften, Forschungszentrum für Geschichte|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=213|language=de}}</ref> The most promininent was in 1953, for the 70th anniversary of Marx's death, and included the renaming of [[Chemnitz]] as Karl-Marx Stadt<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T2mgAAAAMAAJ|title=Travel Guide, German Democratic Republic|last=|first=|date=1983|publisher=Zeit im Bild Publishing House|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=89|language=en}}</ref> and of [[Leipzig University]] as Karl Marx University, the founding of the [[Order of Karl Marx]], and the initiation of the {{ill|Marx-Engels-Werke|de}} project of Marx and Engels' works. The 1968 commemoration marked the 150th anniversary of his birth, and 1983 the 100th anniversary of his death.
[[West Germany]] also commemorated Marx in anniversary years, with prominent renovations/reopenings of the [[Karl Marx House]] in 1968 and 1983. In 2018, [[Trier]] launched its own Karl Marx Year for the 200th anniversary of his birth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.trier.de/kultur-freizeit/karl-marx/karl-marx-jahr-2018/|title=Karl-Marx-Jahr 2018|last=|first=|date=|website=Stadt Trier|language=de|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref>
