[[File:Stolpersteine für die Familien Weichbrod, Stranska und Strauss.jpg|thumb|upright=1.4|Stolpersteine for the families Stránska, Strauss and Weichbrod in front of Petrohradská 155/27, [[Vršovice]]]] The '''Stolpersteine in Prague-Vršovice and Modřany''' lists the [[Stolpersteine]] in the town quarters [[Vršovice]] (Praha 10) and [[Modřany]] (Praha 12). Stolpersteine is the German name for stumbling blocks collocated all over Europe by German artist [[Gunter Demnig]]. They remember the fate of the Nazi victims being murdered, deported, exiled or driven to suicide. Generally, the stumbling blocks are posed in front of the building where the victims had their last self chosen residence. The name of the Stolpersteine in Czech is: ''Kameny zmizelých''. The list is sortable; the basic order follows the alphabet according to the last name of the victim. == Praha 10: [[Vršovice]] == {|class="wikitable sortable toptextcells" style="width:100%" !class="hintergrundfarbe6 unsortable" width="120px"| Stone !class="hintergrundfarbe6" style ="width:18%;"| Name !class="hintergrundfarbe6" data-sort-type="text" style ="width:22%;"| Location !class="hintergrundfarbe6 unsortable" style="width:100%;"| Life and death |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Margita Stranska.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Margita|Stránská|nl=1}} | Petrohradská 155/27
{{Coord|50.066413|14.452008|name=Stolpersteine for Margita and Marta Stránská, Richard Stránský and Valentina Straussová, Kurt and Markus Weichbrod und Adéla Weichbrodová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Margita Stránská was born in [[Rumburg]] on 2 April 1921. Her first name was also spelled Margareta. She was the daughter of Richard Stránský and Marta née Strauss. Prior to Nazi destruction of Czechoslovakia she lived in [[Rumburg]], later on in [[Mladá Vožice]]. On 4 September 1942 she was deported from Prague to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]] with transport Bd, together with her mother and her father. On 8 September 1942 she was deported to [[Maly Trostenets extermination camp]] with transport Bk, train Da 226, again with her parents. All three killed were during the [[Shoah]]. Her grand mother Valentina Straussová was murdered in November 1943 in Theresienstadt. There are two reports on Margita Stránská in [[Yad Vashem]]. One is based on the [[Theresienstädter Gedenkbuch]], the other one was filed by Herta Fridman, her aunt.[[The Central Data Base of Shoah Victims' Names]], Yad Vashem: ''[https://yvng.yadvashem.org/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=4888943&ind=1&winId=3105441484506409917 MARGITA STRANSKA]'', retrieved on 24 February 2017[[The Central Data Base of Shoah Victims' Names]], Yad Vashem: ''[https://yvng.yadvashem.org/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=731462&ind=2&winId=3105441484506409917 MARGIT STRANSKY]'', retrieved on 24 February 2017 |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Marta Stranska.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Marta|Stránská|nl=1}}
née Strauss | Petrohradská 155/27
{{Coord|50.066413|14.452008|name=Stolpersteine for Margita and Marta Stránská, Richard Stránský and Valentina Straussová, Kurt and Markus Weichbrod und Adéla Weichbrodová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Marta Stránská née Strauss was born in [[Chřibská]] on 20 March 1899. She was the daughter of Gottlieb Strauss and Valentina née Weisskopf. She was a housewife and married to Richard Stránský. The couple had a daughter called Margita. Prior to Nazi destruction of Czechoslovakia she lived in [[Mladá Vožice]]. On 4 September 1942 she was deported from Prague to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]] with transport Bd, together with her husband and her daughter. On 8 September 1942 the family was deported to [[Maly Trostenets extermination camp]] with transport Bk, train Da 226, and all three were killed there. Her mother was murdered in November 1943 in Theresienstadt. There are two reports on Marta Stránská in [[Yad Vashem]]. One is based on the [[Theresienstädter Gedenkbuch]], the other one was filed by Yohan Hanus Grab, a family member who as a child lived in [[Plzeň]] during the Nazi occupation.[[The Central Data Base of Shoah Victims' Names]], Yad Vashem: ''[https://yvng.yadvashem.org/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=4889043&ind=4 MARTA STRANSKA]'', retrieved on 24 February 2017[[The Central Data Base of Shoah Victims' Names]], Yad Vashem: ''[https://yvng.yadvashem.org/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=4430433&ind=1 MARTA STRANSKA]'', retrieved on 24 February 2017 |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Richard Stransky.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Richard|Stránský|nl=1}} | Petrohradská 155/27
{{Coord|50.066413|14.452008|name=Stolpersteine for Margita and Marta Stránská, Richard Stránský and Valentina Straussová, Kurt and Markus Weichbrod und Adéla Weichbrodová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Richard Stránský was born in [[Mladá Boleslav]] in 1889. His first name sometimes is also spelled Rickard. He became a merchant and married Marta née Straussová. The couple had a daughter called Margita. On 4 September 1942 he was deported from Prague to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]] with transport Bd, together with his wife and his daughter. On 8 September 1942 the family was deported to [[Maly Trostenets extermination camp]] with transport Bk, train Da 226, and all three were killed during the [[Shoah]]. There are two reports on Richard Stránský in [[Yad Vashem]]. One is based on the [[Theresienstädter Gedenkbuch]], the other one was filed by Herta Fridman, his surviving sister-in-law.[[The Central Data Base of Shoah Victims' Names]], Yad Vashem: ''[https://yvng.yadvashem.org/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=4890479&ind=4 RICHARD STRANSKY]'', retrieved on 24 February 2017[[The Central Data Base of Shoah Victims' Names]], Yad Vashem: ''[https://yvng.yadvashem.org/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=1423704&ind=0&winId=3105441484506409917 RICHARD STRANSKI]'', retrieved on 24 February 2017 |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Valentina Straussova.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Valentina|Straussová|nl=1}} | Petrohradská 155/27
{{Coord|50.066413|14.452008|name=Stolpersteine for Margita and Marta Stránská, Richard Stránský and Valentina Straussová, Kurt and Markus Weichbrod und Adéla Weichbrodová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Valentina Straussová née Weisskopf was born in [[Morchenstern]] in 1874. She was the daughter of Yitzkhak Weisskopf and Matilda. She was a housewife and married to Gottlieb Strauss. The couple had at least three daughters, Herta, Adéla and Marta. On 16 November 1942 she was deported from Tabor to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]] with transport Cb. She lost her life there on 5 November 1943. Her daughters Adéla and Marta, their husbands Markus and Richard as well as her grand children Kurt and Margita were also murdered by the Nazi regime. There are two reports on Valentina Straussová in [[Yad Vashem]]. One is based on the [[Theresienstädter Gedenkbuch]], the other one was filed by her daughter Herta Fridman.[[The Central Data Base of Shoah Victims' Names]], Yad Vashem: ''[https://yvng.yadvashem.org/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=4788229&ind=2 VALENTINA STRAUSSOVA]'', retrieved on 24 February 2017[[The Central Data Base of Shoah Victims' Names]], Yad Vashem: ''[https://yvng.yadvashem.org/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=1484726&ind=26 VALENTINA STRAUSS]'', retrieved on 24 February 2017 Altogether, Herta Fridman submitted 39 reports on murdered family members to Yad Vashem.[[The Central Data Base of Shoah Victims' Names]], Yad Vashem: ''[https://yvng.yadvashem.org/index.html?language=en&advancedSearch=true&sln_value=Fridman&sln_type=synonyms&sfn_value=Herta&sfn_type=synonyms Submitter Herta Friedman]'', retrieved on 24 February 2017 |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Rudolf Vogl.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Rudolf|Vogl|nl=1}} | Slovinská 1041/6
{{Coord|50.070278|14.452008|name=Stolpersteine for Rudolf Vogl and Kamila Voglová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Rudolf Vogl was born on 1 October 1907 in [[Radějovice u Netonic]]. His parents were Emanuel Vogl and Regina née Fuchsová. He had at least two sisters, Anna and Kamila. The family moved to Prague before 1910. His younger sister was already born there. Rudolf Vogl as an employee and a worker. In 1939, his emigration to Cuba was granted but did not take place. In November 1940, he requested the permit to emigrate to Shanghai. Finally he received the permit one year later, but again could not realize his plans. On 30 January 1942 he was deported with transport V from Prague to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]], together with his sister Kamila. His transport number was 1000. On 13 June 1942 he was deported with transport AAi to [[Sobibór extermination camp]], again together with his sister Kamila. His transport number was 168. Both Rudolf Vogl and his sister were murdered by the Nazi regime.holocaust.cz: ''[http://www.holocaust.cz/de/opferdatenbank/opfer/131163-rudolf-vogl/ RUDOLF VOGL]'', retrieved on 28 February 2017 His parents had already died in 1940 or earlier. His elder sister Anna Voglová was also killed during the [[Shoah]]. |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Anna Voglova.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Anna|Voglová|nl=1}} | Slovinská 760/17
{{Coord|50.070195|14.458622|name=Stolperstein for Anna Voglová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Anna Voglová was born on 1 May 1899 in [[Radějovice u Netonic]]. Her parents were Emanuel Vogl and Regina née Fuchsová. She had at least two siblings, brother Rudolf and sister Kamila. The family moved to Prague before 1910. Her sister was already born there. Anna Voglová was deported with transport AAh from Prague to [[Ujazdów, Włodawa County|Ujazdow]] on 10 June 1942. Her transport number was 324 of 1000. Only three Jews of this transport could survive the [[Shoah]]. Anna Voglová was amongst the 997 murdered by the Nazi regime.holocaust.cz: ''[http://www.holocaust.cz/en/database-of-victims/victim/147850-anna-voglova/ ANNA VOGLOVÁ]'', retrieved on 26 February 2017 According to a document issued for her brother Rudolf, the parents of Anna Voglová were already dead in 1940. Her brother and her sister were both deported half a year before her own deportation. None survived the [[Shoah]]. |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Kamila Voglova.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Kamila|Voglová|nl=1}} | Slovinská 1041/6
{{Coord|50.070278|14.452008|name=Stolpersteine for Rudolf Vogl and Kamila Voglová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Kamila Voglová was born on 3 February 1910 in [[Prague]]. Her parents were Emanuel Vogl and Regina née Fuchsová. He had at least two siblings, sister Anna and brother Rudolf. The family moved to Prague somewhere between 1907 and 1910. She worked as a lady's dressmaker. On 30 January 1942 she was deported with transport V from Prague to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]], together with her brother Rudolf. Her transport number was 144. On 13 June 1942 he was deported with transport AAi to [[Sobibór extermination camp]], again together with his sister Kamila. Her transport number was 507. Both brother and sister were murdered by the Nazi regime.holocaust.cz: ''[http://www.holocaust.cz/de/opferdatenbank/opfer/131134-kamila-voglova/ KAMILA VOGLOVÁ]'', retrieved on 28 February 2017 Her parents had already died in 1940 or earlier. Her elder sister Anna Voglová was also killed during the [[Shoah]]. |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Kurt Weichbrod.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Kurt|Weichbrod|nl=1}} | Petrohradská 155/27
{{Coord|50.066413|14.452008|name=Stolpersteine for Margita and Marta Stránská, Richard Stránský and Valentina Straussová, Kurt and Markus Weichbrod und Adéla Weichbrodová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Kurt Weichbrod was born on 12 August 1930. His grand mother was Valenina Straussová, his parents were Markus Weichbrod and Adela née Straussová. On 24 April 1942 he and his parents were deported with transport Am from Prague to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]]. His transport number was 123. Four days later, on 28 April 1942, he and his parents were deported with transport Ar to [[Zamošč]]. His transport number was 744. The eleven-year-old boy and his parents did not survive the [[Shoah]].holocaust.cz: ''[http://www./de/opferdatenbank/opfer/132126-kurt-weichbrod/ KURT WEICHBROD]'', retrieved on 1 March 2017 |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Markus Weichbrod.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Markus|Weichbrod|nl=1}} | Petrohradská 155/27
{{Coord|50.066413|14.452008|name=Stolpersteine for Margita and Marta Stránská, Richard Stránský and Valentina Straussová, Kurt and Markus Weichbrod und Adéla Weichbrodová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Markus Mechel Weichbrod was born on 24 December 1896. He married Adela née Straussová. The couple had one son, Kurt, born in 1930. On 24 April 1942 he, his wife and his son were deported with transport Am from Prague to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]]. His transport number was 121. Four days later, on 28 April 1942, the family was deported with transport Ar to [[Zamošč]]. His transport number was 742. Markus Weichbrod, his wife and his son were murdered in the course of the [[Shoah]].holocaust.cz: ''[http://www.holocaust.cz/de/opferdatenbank/opfer/132128-markus-mechel-weichbrod/ MARKUS MECHEL WEICHBROD]'', retrieved on 1 March 2017 |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Adela Weichbrodova.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Adéla|Weichbrodová|nl=1}} | Petrohradská 155/27
{{Coord|50.066413|14.452008|name=Stolpersteine for Margita and Marta Stránská, Richard Stránský and Valentina Straussová, Kurt and Markus Weichbrod und Adéla Weichbrodová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Adéla Weichbrodová née Straussová was born on 21 Juni 1901 in [[Chřibská]]. Her parents were Gottlieb Strauss and Valentina née Weisskopf. She married Markus Mechel Weichbrod and was a housewife. The couple had one son, Kurt, born in 1930. On 24 April 1942 she, her husband and her son were deported with transport Am from Prague to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]]. Her transport number was 122. Four days later, on 28 April 1942, the family was deported with transport Ar to [[Zamošč]]. Her transport number was 743.Adéla Weichbrodová, her husband and her son were murdered in the course of the [[Shoah]].holocaust.cz: ''[http://www.holocaust.cz/de/opferdatenbank/opfer/132123-adela-weichbrodova/ ADÉLA WEICHBRODOVÁ]'', retrieved on 1 March 2017 |} == Praha 12: [[Modřany]] == {|class="wikitable sortable toptextcells" style="width:100%" !class="hintergrundfarbe6 unsortable" width="120px"| Stone !class="hintergrundfarbe6" style ="width:18%;"| Name !class="hintergrundfarbe6" data-sort-type="text" style ="width:22%;"| Location !class="hintergrundfarbe6 unsortable" style="width:100%;"| Life and death |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Valerie Freundova.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Valerie|Freundová |nl=1}}
née Stern | Dostojevského 931/5
{{Coord|49.997635|14.411367|name=Stolpersteine for Valerie und Zuzinka Freundová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Valerie Freundová née Stern was born on 13 October 1902. She was the daughter of Hugo Stern, also Jizchak or Jehuda, and Marie, also Mirjam. She married Walter Freund. The couple had at least one daughter named Zuzinka, born in 1933. Both mother and daughter were deported with transport Ck from Prague to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]] on 22 December 1942. Her transport number was 931 of 1005. On 4 October 1944 both were deported with transport En to [[Auschwitz concentration camp]]. Her transport number was 259 of 1500. Both mother and daughter were murdered by the Nazi regime in Auschwitz.waymarking.com: ''[http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WMC85F_Freundov_Valerie_Freundov_Zuzinka_Prague_CZ Freundová Valerie, Freundová Zuzinka, Prague, CZ]'', retrieved on 23 February 2017[[The Central Database of Shoah Victims' Names]]: ''[http://db.yadvashem.org/deportation/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=4860982 Valerie Freundova]'', retrieved on 26 February 2017 The report to [[Yad Vashem]] was submitted by her niece Dina Kühne-Stern in 1998. The niece then lived in Switzerland.[[The Central Database of Shoah Victims' Names]]: ''[http://yvng.yadvashem.org/nameDetails.html?language=en&itemId=882436&ind=6 VALERIE FREUNDOVA]'', retrieved on 26 February 2017 |- | [[File:Stolperstein für Zuzinka Freundova.jpg|120px]] | {{SortKeyName|Zuzinka|Freundová |nl=1}} | Dostojevského 931/5
{{Coord|49.997635|14.411367|name=Stolpersteine for Valerie und Zuzinka Freundová|type:landmark_region:CZ|format=dms}} | Zuzinka Freundová, also known as Zuzana, was born on 27 April 1933. She was the daughter of Walter Freund and Valerie née Stern. Together with her mother she was deported on 22 December 1942 with transport Ck to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp]]. Her transport number was 932 of 1005. On 4 October 1944 she was deported with transport En to [[Auschwitz concentration camp]]. Her transport number was 260 of 1500. The eleven-year-old girl and her mother were both murdered in Auschwitz.holocaust.cz: ''[http://www.holocaust.cz/en/database-of-victims/victim/86258-zuzana-freundova/ ZUZANA FREUNDOVÁ]'', retrieved on 23 February 2017 |} == Dates of collocations == According to the website of Gunter Demnig the Stolpersteine of Prague were posed on 8 October 2008, 7 November 2009, 12 June 2010, 13 to 15 June 2011 and on 17 July 2013 by the artist himself. Another collocation, not credited on Demnig's website, took place on 28 October 2012. The Czech Stolperstein project was initiated in 2008 by the ''Česká unie židovské mládeže'' (Czech Union of Jewish Youth) and was realized with the patronage of the Mayor of Prague.Zdeňka Kuchyňová: ''[http://www.radio.cz/cz/rubrika/udalosti/praha-ma-na-chodnicich-sve-prvni-pametni-kameny-holocaustu Praha má na chodnících své první pamětní kameny holocaustu]'', [[Radio Praha]], 19 October 2008stolpersteine.cz: ''[https://archive.is/6bh0z#selection-293.1-293.45 archive.is/6bh0z Stolpersteine in der Tschechischen Republik]'', retrieved on 20 March 2017 (German) == See also == * [[List of cities by country that have stolpersteine]] * [[Stolpersteine in the Czech Republic]] ==External links== {{Commonscat|Stolpersteine in Prague}} * [http://www.stolpersteine.eu/chronik/ stolpersteine.eu], Demnig's website * [http://www.holocaust.cz/en/main-2/ holocaust.cz] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Cities By Country That Have Stolpersteine}} [[Category:Stolpersteine in Prague|Vršovice and Modřany]] [[Category:Holocaust memorials]] [[Category:Lists of monuments and memorials|Stolpersteine]] [[Category:Holocaust commemoration]]

[[Hungarian Democratic People's Party|MDNP]] | otherparty = |}} {{eastern name order|Katona Tamás}} '''Tamás Katona''' (February 2, 1932 – June 28, 2013)[http://hetivalasz.hu/itthon/negy-evig-a-magyar-cserkesz-szovetseget-is-vezette-65609/ Meghalt Katona Tamás történész, az Antall-kormány egykori államtitkára], hetivalasz.hu (Hozzáférés: 2013. június 29.) was a Hungarian historian, academic, politician, who served as Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs from 1990 to 1992 and as Mayor of Budavár (1st district of [[Budapest]]) between 1994 and 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.parlament.hu/kepviselo/elet/k071.htm |title=''Biography'' |publisher=[[National Assembly of Hungary|Országgyűlés]]}} Besides that he represented [[Vác]] ([[Pest County]] Constituency II) in the [[National Assembly of Hungary]] from 1990 to 1994, and functioned as MP from the [[Hungarian Democratic Forum]]'s Pest County Regional List between 1994 and 1998.{{cite web|url=http://www.parlament.hu/internet/plsql/ogy_kpv.kepv_adat?p_azon=k071&p_ckl=34 |title=''Register'' |publisher=[[National Assembly of Hungary|Országgyűlés]]}} Katona served as President of the [[Hungarian Scout Association]] between 1994 and 1998. {{Use British English|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox writer | name = William Dalrymple | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FRSL|FRGS|FRSE|size=100%}} | image = William_Dalrymple_2014.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Dalrymple in 2014 | birth_name = William Hamilton-Dalrymple | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1965|3|20|df=y}} | alma_mater = [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] | birth_place = Scotland | occupation = Writer, historian | nationality = Scottish | residence = [[Delhi]], India | period = 1989–present | subject = India, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Middle East, Eastern Christianity, Muslim World, Christian-Muslim relations, religious syncretism | spouse = Olivia Fraser | website = {{URL|http://www.williamdalrymple.uk.com}} }}
'''William Dalrymple''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|FRSL|FRGS|FRSE}} (born '''William Hamilton-Dalrymple''' on 20 March 1965) is a Scottish historian and writer, art historian and curator, as well as a prominent broadcaster and critic.
His books have won numerous awards and prizes, including the Duff Cooper Memorial Prize, the Thomas Cook Travel Book Award, the Sunday Times Young British Writer of the Year Award, the Hemingway, the Kapuściński and the Wolfson Prizes. He has been four times longlisted and once shortlisted for the [[Samuel Johnson Prize]] for non-fiction. He is also one of the co-founders and co-directors of the annual [[Jaipur Literature Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2009-01-27/the-greatest-literary-show-on-earth|title =The Greatest Literary Show on Earth|accessdate = 3 February 2009|publisher =The Daily Beast}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.kiwicollection.com/around_world_detail/ITEM=242/|title = Looking for something special? Try treasure hunting in India|accessdate = 22 April 2008|publisher = KiwiCollection.com|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080602040759/http://www.kiwicollection.com/around_world_detail/ITEM%3D242/|archivedate = 2 June 2008|df = dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url =http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/StoryPage.aspx?id=0640ff75-70ec-460d-8d06-a9bfc6d124aa |title =Writes of passage|date = 30 January 2008|accessdate =23 April 2008|publisher =Hindustan Times}}</ref>
In 2012 he was appointed a Whitney J. Oates Visiting Fellow in the Humanities by [[Princeton University]].<ref>[http://humanities.princeton.edu/fellows/short-term-visiting-fellows Short-Term Visiting Fellows], Princeton University ''retrieved 1 October 2012''.</ref> In the Spring of 2015 he was appointed the OP Jindal Distinguished Lecturer at [[Brown University]].<ref>[http://www.brown.edu/initiatives/india/opjindal/william-dalrymple], Brown University ''retrieved 28 April 2015''.</ref>
In 2018 he was awarded the [[President's Medal (British Academy)|President's Medal]] of the [[British Academy]].<ref name="britac.ac.uk">{{cite web |title=Award-winning journalists, prehistorians and world-leading economists honoured with prestigious British Academy prizes and medals |url=https://www.britac.ac.uk/news/journalists-prehistorians-economists-honoured-british-academy-prizes-medals |website=British Academy |accessdate=5 September 2018 |date=20 August 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Dalrymple is the son of [[Sir Hew Hamilton-Dalrymple, 10th Baronet]], and Lady Anne-Louise Keppel. He is a cousin of [[Virginia Woolf]]. He was educated at [[Ampleforth College]] and [[Trinity College, Cambridge]], where he was first a history [[Exhibition (scholarship)|exhibitioner]] and then a senior history scholar.<ref>{{citeweb|url=https://www.williamdalrymple.uk.com/biog |title=Biography – William Dalrymple}}</ref>
Dalrymple first went to [[Delhi]] on 26 January 1984.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Last Mughal|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-0-143-10243-4|page=6|author=William Dalrymple|chapter=Introduction}}</ref> Dalrymple has lived in India on and off since 1989 and spends most of the year at his [[Mehrauli]] farmhouse in the outskirts of Delhi,<ref name="bookforum1">{{cite news |title=The Don of Dehli |author=Karan Mahajan |url=http://www.bookforum.com/inprint/017_05/7000 |newspaper=Bookforum.com|date=February–March 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref> but summers in London and Edinburgh. His wife Olivia is an artist and comes from a family with long-standing connections to India. They have three children, Ibby, Sam, and Adam.
He is a [[Roman Catholicism|Roman Catholic]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Dalrymple |first=William |title=From the Holy Mountain: A Journey among the Christians of the Middle East |location=New York |publisher=H. Holt |year=1998 |page=10}}</ref>
==Interests and influence== [[File:William Dalrymple.jpg|thumb|200px|William Dalrymple (left) with [[Esther Freud]] (centre) and [[Hanan Ashrawi]] at [[PalFest]] 2008.]] Dalrymple's interests include the history and art of India, Pakistan, Afghanistan, the Middle East, the Muslim world, Hinduism, Buddhism, the [[Jainism|Jains]] and early Eastern Christianity. All of his eight books have won literary prizes. His first three were travel books based on his journeys in the Middle East, India and Central Asia. His early influences included travel writers such as [[Robert Byron]],<ref>https://literature.britishcouncil.org/writer/william-dalrymple</ref> [[Eric Newby]], and [[Bruce Chatwin]]. More recently, Dalrymple published a book of essays about current affairs in the Indian Subcontinent, and two award-winning histories of the interaction between the British and the Mughals between the eighteenth and mid nineteenth century. His books have been translated into more than 40 languages.
He is a regular contributor to ''[[The New York Review of Books]]'',<ref name="nybooks.com">{{cite web |url = http://www.nybooks.com/authors/9809 |title = Book review by William Dalrymple |accessdate = 30 June 2007 |work = [[The New York Review of Books]]}}</ref> ''[[The Guardian]]'',<ref>{{cite news |url = http://commentisfree.guardian.co.uk/william_dalrymple/index.html |title = Articles by William Dalrymple |accessdate = 30 June 2007 |publisher = GuardianUnlimited |location=London}}</ref> the ''[[New Statesman]]''<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.newstatesman.com/writers/william_dalrymple |title = Articles by William Dalrymple |accessdate = 30 June 2007 |work = The New York Review of Books}}</ref> and ''[[The New Yorker]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.newyorker.com/search/query?queryType=nonparsed&query=%22William+Dalrymple%22&submit.x=0&submit.y=0&submit=Submit&bylquery=&month1=-1&day1=-1&year1=-1&month2=-1&day2=-1&year2=-1&page=&sort= |title = Articles by William Dalrymple |accessdate = 30 June 2007 |publisher = The New Yorker}}</ref> He has also written many articles for [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine. He has been the Indian Subcontinent correspondent of the ''[[New Statesman]]'' since 2004.
He attended the inaugural [[Palestine Festival of Literature]] in 2008 – giving readings and taking workshops in [[Jerusalem]], [[Ramallah]] and [[Bethlehem]].<ref name="CAABU">{{cite news |url =http://www.caabu.org/events/caabu/caabu-reception-evening-william-dalrymple |title =Caabu Reception: An evening with William Dalrymple |accessdate =5 October 2012 |publisher =The Council for Arab-British Understanding}}</ref>
His 2009 book, ''Nine Lives: In Search of the Sacred in Modern India'', was published by Bloomsbury, and went to the number one slot on the Indian non-fiction section best-seller list.<ref>{{cite news |url =http://www.hindustantimes.com/rssfeed/bestsellers/William-s-new-book-tops-bestseller-list/Article1-467856.aspx |title =William's new book tops bestseller list |date =22 October 2009 |accessdate =28 October 2009 |publisher =Hindustan Times}}</ref> Since its publication he has been touring the UK, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Australia, Holland and the US with a band consisting of some of the people featured in his book including [[Sufis]], [[Fakirs]], [[Bauls]], Theveram hymn singers as well as a prison warder and part-time [[Theyyam]] dancer widely believed to be an incarnation of the God [[Vishnu]].<ref>{{cite web |url =http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/0acfc01e-a3e1-11de-9fed-00144feabdc0.html |title =On Tour with the Madmen |date =18 September 2009 |publisher =Financial Times }}</ref>
''Return of a King- The Battle for Afghanistan'', a history of the [[First Anglo-Afghan War|First Afghan War 1839–42]], was published in India in December 2012,<ref name="ZeeNews">[http://zeenews.india.com/entertainment/bookworm/william-dalrymple-s-book-on-first-anglo-afghan-war-out-in-december_2501.htm William Dalrymple`s book on first Anglo-Afghan war out in December] Zee News</ref><ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-2244901/William-Dalrymple-takes-swipe-Empire.html Author William Dalrymple takes a swipe at the Empire] Daily Mail 7 December 2012</ref> in the UK in February 2013, and in the US in April 2013. Dalrymple's great-great-granduncle [[Colin Mackenzie (Indian Army officer)|Colin Mackenzie]] fought in the war and was briefly detained by the Afghans. Following the publication of the book Dalrymple was called to brief both the Afghan President [[Hamid Karzai]] and the [[White House]] on the lessons to be learned from Afghan history.{{fact?|date=June 2017}}
Dalrymple was also the curator of ''Princes and Painters in Mughal Delhi 1707–1857'', a major show of the late Mughal and Company School painting for the ''[[Asia Society]]'' in New York, which ran from February to May 2012.<ref name="AS1">[http://sites.asiasociety.org/princesandpainters/ Princes and Painters], Asia Society retrieved 4 October 2012.</ref> A catalogue of this exhibit co-edited by Dalrymple with Yuthika Sharma was published by Penguin in 2012 under the same name.<ref name="ZeeNews"/>
He is currently working on ''The Anarchy'', a history of the Indian Subcontinent during the period 1739–1803 which saw the collapse of the Mughal imperial system, rise of the Maratha imperial confederacy, and the militarisation and rise of power of the [[East India Company]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/04/east-india-company-original-corporate-raiders }}</ref>
==Works== *''[[In Xanadu]]'' (1989) *''[[City of Djinns|City of Djinns: A Year in Delhi]]'' (1994) *''[[From the Holy Mountain|From the Holy Mountain: A Journey in the Shadow of Byzantium]]'' (1997) *''[[The Age of Kali]]'' (1998) *''[[White Mughals]]'' (2002) *''[[Begums Thugs And White Mughals|Begums, Thugs & White Mughals: The Journals of Fanny Parkes]]'' (2002) *''[[The Last Mughal|The Last Mughal, The Fall of a Dynasty, Delhi 1857]]'' (2006) *''[[Nine Lives: In Search of the Sacred in Modern India]]''. ==Popular culture==
===TV and radio=== Dalrymple has written and presented the six-part television series ''Stones of the Raj'' (Channel 4, August 1997),<ref>{{cite web |url = http://ftvdb.bfi.org.uk/sift/series/28568 |title = Stones of the Raj |accessdate = 18 August 2007 |publisher = British Film Institute}}</ref> the three-part ''Indian Journeys'' (BBC, August 2002)<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.indiantelevision.com/headlines/y2k2/aug/aug107.htm |title = BBC World to premiere Indian Journeys 20 August |accessdate = 18 August 2007 |publisher = Channel 4}}</ref> and ''Sufi Soul'' (Channel 4, Nov 2005).<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.channel4.com/culture/microsites/C/can_you_believe_it/debates/sufi.html |title = Sufi Soul |accessdate = 18 August 2007 |publisher = Channel 4 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070612183013/http://www.channel4.com/culture/microsites/C/can_you_believe_it/debates/sufi.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 12 June 2007}}</ref>
The six-part ''Stones of the Raj'' documents the stories behind some of British India's colonial architecture starting with ''Lahore'' (16 August 1997), ''Calcutta'' (23 August 1997), ''The French Connection'' (30 August 1997), ''The Fatal Friendship'' (6 September 1997), ''Surrey in Tibet'' (13 September 1997), and concluded with ''The Magnificent Ruin'' (20 September 1997).
The trilogy of ''Indian Journeys'' consists of three one-hour episodes starting with ''Shiva’s Matted Locks'' which while tracing the source of the Ganga, takes Dalrymple on a journey to the Himalayas. The second part ''City of Djinns'', is based on his travel book of the same name, takes a look at Delhi's history, and last ''Doubting Thomas'', which takes Dalrymple to the Indian states of [[Kerala]] and [[Tamil Nadu]], where [[Thomas the Apostle|St Thomas, the Apostle]] of Jesus is closely associated.<ref>{{cite news |url = http://www.mid-day.com/entertainment/television/2002/august/28541.htm |date = 9 August 2002 |title = The voyager – William Dalrymple |accessdate = 17 August 2007 |publisher = Mid Day}}</ref>
He has done a six-part history series ''The Long Search'' for Radio 4.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2002/05_may/27/long_search.shtml |title = The Long Search |accessdate = 18 August 2007 |publisher = BBC}}</ref> In this series Dalrymple searches to discover the spiritual roots of the British Isles. As Dalrymple says "In the course of my travels I often came across the assumption that intense spirituality was somehow the preserve of what many call 'the mystic East'... it's a misconception that has always irritated me as I've always regarded our own indigenous British traditions of spirituality as especially rich."
The BBC broadcast an acclaimed documentary on 3 September 2015 entitled ''Love and Betrayal in India: The White Mughal'',<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/articles/18SDBJqWwgc7VLDM7MhGK2S/a-love-story-that-broke-the-conventional-boundaries-of-empire A love story that broke the conventional boundaries of Empire] BBC September 2015</ref> based on Dalrymple's book ''White Mughals''.
